On May 7, 2010, Commissioner [[Don Garber]] announced that Saputo and the [[Montreal Impact|Impact]] group would join the league as its 19th club for the [[2012 Major League Soccer season|2012 MLS season]] with [[Saputo Stadium|Stade Saputo]] being renovated to increase the seating capacity to around 20,000.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://montrealgazette.com/Long+wait+over+Impact+joins/3001135/story.html |title= Long wait over as Impact joins MLS |work= The Gazette|location=Montreal|date= May 7, 2010 |accessdate= February 10, 2013}}</ref>
=== Dissolution of Chivas USA (2014) === {{See also|Chivas USA}}
Chivas USA was dissolved following the end of the [[2014 Chivas USA season|2014 regular season]], after the league bought the franchise and took over the operations from [[Jorge Vergara]] and [[Angélica Fuentes]] in February that year, leaving the league with 20 teams for the 2015 season. The club had suffered poor performance on the field, low attendance and a series of discrimination lawsuits against the ownership.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/chivas-usa/story/2112968/mls-shuts-down-chivas-usanew-clubownership-to-return-in-2017|title=MLS shuts down Chivas USA; new club, ownership to return in 2017|first=Jeff|last=Carlisle|publisher=ESPN FC|date=October 27, 2014|accessdate=October 28, 2014}}</ref> Commissioner Garber cited the "brand that was targeted specifically to the Hispanic market" and the belief that "the club could coexist with the [[Los Angeles Galaxy|Galaxy]] and share the [[StubHub Center]]" as mistakes.<ref name="Chivas Ives">{{cite news | title = With Chivas USA a memory, MLS commish looks ahead to new LA team | work = Soccer By Ives | url = http://www.soccerbyives.net/2014/10/discusses-failures-torres.html | accessdate = October 28, 2014 | date = October 28, 2014 | first = Ryan | last = Tolmich}}</ref>
Later the same week, the league announced the formation of a new Los Angeles-area team that began play in 2018 with the working name, "Los Angeles Football Club".<ref name="LAFC">{{cite news | title = MLS officials to announce details of new franchise replacing Chivas USA | url = http://www.dailynews.com/sports/20141030/mls-officials-to-announce-details-of-new-franchise-replacing-chivas-usa | work = Los Angeles Times | date = October 30, 2014 | accessdate = October 30, 2014}}</ref>
=== New York City and Orlando (2015) === {{main|New York City FC|Orlando City SC}}
In May 2010, league commissioner [[Don Garber]] announced the league's desire to place its 20th team in New York City<ref name="Sports.espn.go.com">{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/soccer/news/story?id=5170713 |title=MLS to play in Montreal in 2012 |work=ESPN Sports |date=May 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}}</ref> On June 27, 2012, MLS announced plans to build a new [[New York City FC Stadium|soccer-specific stadium]] in [[Queens]], [[New York (state)|New York]], with a seating capacity of 25,000 and located near the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in [[Flushing Meadows – Corona Park|Flushing Meadows]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Oshan |first=Jeremiah |url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2012/6/27/3122008/mls-expansion-new-york-city |title=Plans To Bring MLS Expansion Team To New York City Proper Take Step Forward |publisher=SBNation.com |accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> On May 21, 2013, MLS announced [[New York City FC]] as the next expansion team. The team's expansion rights were purchased by the [[English Premier League]] club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[New York Yankees]] baseball team for $100 million, and the team began play in 2015.<ref name="NYT">{{Cite journal |title=Manchester City and Yankees to Own M.L.S. Franchise in New York |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/22/sports/soccer/manchester-city-and-yankees-to-own-mls-franchise-in-new-york.html|journal=The New York Times |date=May 21, 2013|accessdate=May 21, 2013 |postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
On October 25, 2010, [[Phil Rawlins]] and his investor group of [[Orlando City SC]], announced their intentions of joining Major League Soccer within the next 3 to 5 years.<ref>{{cite web|author=Simon Borg |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/investors-targeting-mls-club-orlando |title=Investors targeting MLS club for Orlando |work=MLSsoccer.com |date=October 25, 2010 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}}</ref> In March 2012, Garber met with Orlando city and county officials, and said, "It's not a matter of if, but when", when addressing Orlando's chances of joining MLS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2012/03/01/orlando-city-put-mls-ambitions-show-commissioner |title=Orlando City put MLS ambitions on show for Commissioner |work=MLSsoccer.com |date=March 1, 2012 |accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> In April 2013, the City of Orlando purchased downtown land to be used towards the construction of a $110 million MLS soccer stadium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wftv.com/news/news/local/dyer-opens-about-land-purchase-new-mls-stadium/nXPb3/|title=Dyer opens up about land purchase for new MLS stadium|date=April 17, 2013|publisher=WFTV}}</ref> Orange County Mayor Teresa Jacobs and Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer reached an agreement on a deal to provide financial support for a variety of Orlando projects including the new MLS soccer stadium on August 8, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kennedy |first=Paul |url=http://www.socceramerica.com/article/53106/mayors-line-up-behind-orlando-stadium-deal.html |title=Mayors line up behind Orlando stadium deal 08/09/2013 |publisher=SoccerAmerica |date=August 9, 2013 |accessdate=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/05/06/orlando-city-determined-join-mls-despite-legislation-impasse-florida-house-r|title=Orlando City determined to join MLS despite legislation impasse in Florida House|date=May 6, 2013|work=mlssoccer.com}}</ref> The Orange County Board of Commissioners voted 5–2 on October 22, 2013 to approve the use of $20 million in tourist development tax funds to build an $84 million multi-purpose soccer stadium in downtown Orlando.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/10/21/report-mls-will-move-very-quickly-expansion-process-should-final-orlando-cit|title='We are going MLS!' Pro soccer stadium is coming to Orlando|date=October 22, 2013|work=Orlando Sentinel|first=Mark|last=Schlueb|author2=David Damron}} </ref><ref name="SI Atlanta">{{cite news|url=http://soccer.si.com/2013/09/13/mls-expansion-team-likely-heading-atlantas-way/|title=MLS expansion team likely heading Atlanta's way|date=September 13, 2013|work=Sports Illustrated|series=Planet Fútbol|first=Brian|last=Straus|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513153145/http://soccer.si.com/2013/09/13/mls-expansion-team-likely-heading-atlantas-way/|archivedate=May 13, 2014}}</ref> On November 19, 2013, Orlando was officially announced as the league's newest team, and began play in MLS in 2015.<ref name="Orlando MLS Expansion">{{cite web|title=MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER AWARDS EXPANSION TEAM TO ORLANDO|url=http://www.orlandocitysoccer.com/news/?article_id=1655|work=orlandocitysoccer.com|publisher=Orlando City Soccer Club|accessdate=November 20, 2013}}</ref>
=== Atlanta and Minnesota (2017) === {{Main|Atlanta United FC|Minnesota United FC}}
The league announced it was awarding an expansion franchise in [[Atlanta]] to [[Atlanta Falcons]] owner and [[The Home Depot|Home Depot]] co-founder [[Arthur Blank]] on April 16, 2014, with plans to begin play in 2017. The team shares the [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]], which was completed in 2017, with the Falcons.<ref name="Creditor 2014"/> Discussions between Blank and MLS had "accelerated" following approval of the stadium plans in late 2013.<ref name="SI Atlanta"/>
Atlanta became the third city in the southeastern United States in five months to announce an expansion team, following Orlando City in late 2013 and Miami, whose tentative approval was announced earlier in 2014.<ref name="Creditor 2014">{{cite news|title=MLS awards 2017 expansion franchise to Atlanta, owner Arthur Blank|series=Planet Fútbol|work=Sports Illustrated|first=Avi|last=Creditor|url=http://soccer.si.com/2014/04/16/mls-awards-2017-expansion-franchise-to-atlanta-owner-arthur-blank/|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=April 16, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417143740/http://soccer.si.com/2014/04/16/mls-awards-2017-expansion-franchise-to-atlanta-owner-arthur-blank/|archivedate=April 17, 2014}}</ref> The [[Atlanta metropolitan area]] was at the time the largest [[media market]] without an MLS franchise.<ref name="AP 2014">{{cite news| title = Atlanta Lands MLS Expansion Team for 2017|url = http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/wireStory/atlanta-lands-mls-expansion-team-2017-23353432 | accessdate = April 16, 2014 | first = Paul| last = Newberry |date= April 16, 2014| agency=AP Sports}}</ref> Previously, in October 2008, Arthur Blank's AMB Group had submitted a bid for an expansion franchise,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2008-10-14-4126789750_x.htm |title=Falcons owner Blank puts in bid for MLS franchise |work=USA Today|date=October 14, 2008 |accessdate=June 7, 2012}}</ref> but withdrew its bid in early 2009 due to its inability to have a stadium built.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2009/01/12/daily110.html|title=Blank withdraws MLS soccer team bid|date= January 16, 2009|work=Atlanta Business Chronicle|first=John|last=Manasso}}</ref>
On March 25, 2015, the league announced that it had awarded the 23rd MLS team to an investor group in [[Minneapolis–Saint Paul]] led by [[William W. McGuire|Bill McGuire]], owner of the [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] team [[Minnesota United FC (2010–16)|Minnesota United FC]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Major League Soccer team coming to Minneapolis | publisher = Minnesota Public Radio News | url = http://www.mprnews.org/story/2015/03/25/mls-soccer-minneapolis | accessdate = March 25, 2015 | first = Tim | last = Nelson | date = March 25, 2015}}</ref> Club president Nick Rodgers said he expected much of the team, including the name, logo, coach and some players, to remain intact.<ref>{{cite news |title=United president expects team name, logo, coach to stay the same |newspaper=Minneapolis Star Tribune |url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/297599881.html |accessdate=March 26, 2015 |date=March 25, 2015 |first=Rachel |last=Blount}}</ref> In addition to the Minnesota United bid, a group led by the [[Zygi Wilf|Wilf family]], owners of the NFL's [[Minnesota Vikings]], had also been vying for a franchise, to play at the Vikings' new [[U.S. Bank Stadium]], but were unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web|author=Brian Quarstad |url=http://www.insidemnsoccer.com/2012/05/12/mls-commissioner-don-garber-says-minnesota-goes-on-list-with-new-vikings-stadium |title=MLS Commissioner Don Garber Says Minnesota 'Goes on List' with New Vikings Stadium |work=Inside MN Soccer |date=May 12, 2012 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}}</ref> The Wilfs would later become investors in Nashville's successful MLS bid.
The team had been expected to begin play in MLS in 2018, though the timing of their start date was described as "fluid."<ref>{{cite news | title = MLS Commissioner Don Garber: Minneapolis represents everything that is spurring growth of MLS | work= MLSsoccer.com | url = http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/03/25/mls-commissioner-don-garber-minneapolis-represents-everything-spurring-growt | accessdate = March 27, 2015 | date = March 25, 2015 | first = Sam | last = Stejkal}}</ref> The ownership group did not meet its July 1, 2015 deadline to present stadium plans to MLS after the Minnesota state legislature failed to take up the club's proposal by the end of its session in May 2015.<ref>[https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2015/07/01/mls-minnesota-expansion-stadium-deadline-st-paul "MLS's stadium deadline passes, but Minnesota still in play for expansion"], ''Sports Illustrated'', July 2, 2015.</ref> In October 2015, the team announced it had selected [[Allianz Field|a stadium site in St. Paul]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/st-paul-to-get-major-league-soccer/336279821/|title=With team and stadium, St. Paul savors soccer triumph – StarTribune.com|work=Star Tribune|accessdate=November 15, 2015}}</ref> The league later announced that Minnesota United would join MLS in 2017, and would play in Minneapolis at the [[University of Minnesota]]'s [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|football]] home of [[TCF Bank Stadium]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Quarstad|first=Brian|title=Minnesota United to play inaugural MLS season at new home: TCF Bank Stadium|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/08/19/minnesota-united-play-inaugural-mls-season-new-home-tcf-bank-stadium|publisher=Major League Soccer|date=August 19, 2016|accessdate=August 28, 2016}}</ref> until its new stadium was ready.
=== Los Angeles (2018) === {{Main|Los Angeles FC}} On October 30, 2014, the league announced the formation of a new Los Angeles-area team to replace [[Chivas USA]], which shut down operations following the 2014 season. The new team was announced with the working name, "Los Angeles Football Club", which later became its official name in September 2015. LAFC's ownership group is led by venture capitalist Henry Nguyen, film producer [[Peter Guber]], and former [[National Basketball Association]] executive [[Tom Penn]]. The team began play in 2018 in a new soccer-specific stadium,<ref name="LAFC"/> [[Banc of California Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Koren |first=James Rufus |date=August 23, 2016 |title=Banc of California snags naming rights for L.A. Football Club soccer stadium |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-boc-naming-rights-20160822-snap-story.html |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=August 23, 2016}}</ref>
=== Cincinnati (2019) === {{Main|FC Cincinnati}}
[[File:MLS2CINCY town hall - Don Garber raising scarf (31735676666) (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Garber holds up an [[FC Cincinnati (2016–18)|FC Cincinnati]] scarf during his 2016 visit to Cincinnati.]] On November 29, 2016, Don Garber visited with [[Cincinnati]]'s mayor John Cranley, officials from [[FC Cincinnati (2016–18)|FC Cincinnati]] of the USL, and civic and business leaders of the city to talk about a possible expansion. FC Cincinnati, in its first season in the USL in 2016, broke the USL's single-season attendance record, averaging 17,296 fans per game at [[Nippert Stadium]]. They also set the league's single-game playoff record for attendance with 30,187 spectators on October 2. On the heels of those attendance numbers, Cincinnati entered the expansion conversation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/11/15/cincinnati-set-welcome-commissioner-don-garber-push-mls-expansion|title=Cincinnati set to welcome Commissioner Don Garber in push for MLS expansion|publisher=Major League Soccer |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> On June 12, 2017, FC Cincinnati revealed designs for a soccer-specific stadium to be built in conjunction with an MLS bid.<ref>{{cite news|title=FC Cincinnati unveils stadium design, emphasizes Newport at OTR event|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/sports/soccer/fc-cincinnati/2017/06/12/fc-cincinnati-unveils-stadium-design/102795934/|newspaper=Cincinnati.com|accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref> [[FC Cincinnati]] was awarded an expansion on May 29, 2018, to start play in MLS in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3512103/fc-cincinnati-to-join-mls-as-expansion-team-next-season|title=FC Cincinnati to join MLS as expansion team|accessdate=June 4, 2018}}</ref>
== Confirmed expansion teams == {{MLS labeled map}}
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Team !! Announced !! Debut |- | Inter Miami CF || {{start date and age|2014|2|14}} || 2020 |- | Nashville SC || {{start date and age|2017|12|20|}} || 2020 |- | Austin FC || {{start date and age|2019|1|15|}} || 2021 |- | St. Louis || {{start date and age|2019|8|20|}} || 2022 |- | Sacramento Republic || {{start date and age|2019|10|21|}} || 2022
|}
===Miami (2020)=== {{Main|Inter Miami CF}}
Garber confirmed in a July 5, 2013, interview that Miami, Atlanta, Orlando, and Texas were all candidates for MLS expansion.<ref name="Bloomberg TV">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/summertime-is-soccer-time-in-america-0DkiYhYNTCevS6wSInlweQ.html|title=Summertime Is Soccer Time in America|date=July 5, 2013|publisher=Bloomberg TV}}</ref>
On February 5, 2014, the league announced that it would award a franchise in Miami to an investment group led by former player [[David Beckham]], his business partner [[Simon Fuller]], and Miami-based businessman [[Marcelo Claure]], assuming that stadium financing and location could be agreed upon.<ref name="Miami Beckham">{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/02/05/3914127/soccer-star-david-beckham-to-bring.html|title=Soccer star David Beckham to bring MLS team to Miami|work=The Miami Herald|first=Patricia|last=Mazzei|date=February 5, 2014}}</ref> However, the ownership group's two stadium sites were rejected by city and county governments by July 2014.<ref> {{cite news | title = David Beckham's Miami MLS plans on hold until stadium secured | work = Sports Illustrated | date=July 29, 2014 | url = https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2014/07/29/mls-miami-downtown-stadium-david-beckham | accessdate = August 4, 2014 }}</ref>
In an August 2014 Q&A session, deputy commissioner Mark Abbott said Miami would be the 23rd team as long as a downtown stadium deal could be reached.<ref name="SI.com">{{cite news|last1=Bird|first1=Liviu|title=MLS All-Star Notes: Mark Abbott on expansion, Blatter; Training contrast|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/planet-futbol/2014/08/05/mls-all-star-game-bayern-munich-mark-abbott-expansion-tv-blatter|accessdate=August 6, 2014|work=Planet Futbol|date=August 5, 2014}}</ref>
Commissioner Garber said he hoped to see Miami join the league with Atlanta in 2017, but repeated that the team would not play without political support for a downtown stadium.<ref>{{cite news|title=Political will key to Beckham's MLS Miami plan: Garber|url=http://wtaq.com/news/articles/2014/oct/23/political-will-key-to-beckhams-mls-miami-plan-garber/|publisher=WTAQ|first=Simon|last=Evans|date=October 23, 2014}}</ref>
The next development in the Beckham plan came on July 17, 2015, when Miami mayor [[Tomás Pedro Regalado|Tomás Regalado]] announced a tentative deal with the ownership group, now known as Beckham United, for a new privately financed stadium in [[Little Havana]] next to [[Marlins Park]], at the former site of the [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/07/17/beckham-united-miami-mayor-agree-new-mls-stadium-plan |title=Beckham United & Miami mayor agree on new MLS stadium plan |publisher=Major League Soccer |date=July 17, 2015 |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref> However, the plans for the Orange Bowl site fell through later that year after Beckham United was unable to secure deals with private owners of adjacent land.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fieldofschemes.com/2015/11/30/10172/beckham-reportedly-throws-in-towel-on-soccer-stadium-alongside-marlins-park/|title=Beckham reportedly throws in towel on soccer stadium alongside Marlins Park|date=November 30, 2015|first=Neil|last=DeMause|work=Field of Schemes}}</ref>
In December of that year, Beckham United announced that a new stadium site, mostly private land but also containing a tract owned by [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]], had been selected in Miami's [[Overtown (Miami)|Overtown]] neighborhood.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article47939140.html |title=Beckham announces Overtown site for soccer stadium |first1=Douglas|last1= Hanks |first2=David |last2=Smiley |date=December 4, 2015|newspaper=The Miami Herald|accessdate=December 4, 2015}}</ref> The MLS governing board soon approved the location,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/blog/morning-edition/2015/12/mls-approves-miami-beckham-united-expansion.html|title=Major League Soccer approves David Beckham's expansion team in Miami, Overtown location – South Florida Business Journal|author=Brian Bandell|date=December 7, 2015|work=South Florida Business Journal}}</ref> and the Beckham group completed the purchase of the privately owned tracts in March 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article68064887.html |title=David Beckham group buys private land needed for Miami soccer stadium |first1=Douglas |last1=Hanks |first2=David |last2=Smiley |newspaper=The Miami Herald |date=March 24, 2016 |accessdate=November 5, 2016}}</ref> Negotiations with county officials to assemble the final section of the stadium site are ongoing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article76065727.html |title=David Beckham stadium talks with Miami-Dade hit a snag |work=The Miami Herald|author=Douglas Hanks |date= May 6, 2016 |accessdate=August 21, 2016}}</ref>
Beckham had received an option to buy an expansion franchise for $25 million as part of the contract he signed with the league when he joined the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]].<ref name="Beckham option 2014">{{cite news |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/02/03/3908896/beckham-miami-deal-one-step-closer.htmlg |title=Beckham-Miami deal one step closer; local visit plans revealed |first=Michelle |last=Kaufman |work=The Miami Herald |date=February 2, 2014}}</ref>
On January 29, 2018, the MLS officially approved Beckham's expansion team in Miami with play expected to start in 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3361118/mls-finally-announces-david-beckhams-expansion-team-in-miami |title=MLS announces David Beckham's expansion team in Miami |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=January 29, 2018}}</ref>
=== Nashville (2020)=== {{Main|Nashville SC (MLS)}} In August 2016, a group of Nashville business leaders from several of the city's largest corporations formed the Nashville MLS Organizing Committee and began efforts to secure funding for an MLS stadium.<ref>[http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/12/19/tennessee-legislature-proposes-bill-help-fund-nashville-mls-stadium"Tennessee legislature proposes bill to help fund Nashville MLS stadium"], MLS Soccer, December 19, 2016.</ref> The group, led by Bill Hagerty, pursued an MLS team immediately rather than work up the soccer pyramid. The group fully supports the recently awarded USL expansion team, [[Nashville SC]], which began play in 2018. Both groups support each other in their common vision to grow the sport in Tennessee.<ref>[http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/08/09/nashville-business-leaders-form-group-bring-mls-music-city"Nashville business leaders form group to bring MLS to the Music City"], MLS Soccer, August 9, 2016.</ref> In October 2017, the group unveiled their plans for $275 million stadium and redevelopment project,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nashvillepost.com/business/development/article/20980225/soccer-stadium-backers-detail-redevelopment-plans |title=Soccer stadium backers detail redevelopment plans |work=[[Nashville Post]] |date=October 23, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/10/24/nashville-mls-stadium-supporters-pack-hearing-fairgrounds-proposal/790117001/ |title=Nashville soccer fans come out in force for $275M MLS stadium proposal |work=[[The Tennessean]] |date=October 24, 2017}}</ref> which was approved by the city in November.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/major-league-soccer/story/3263044/nashville-mls-expansion-bid-gets-boost-from-initial-$275m-stadium-approval |title=Nashville MLS expansion bid gets boost from $275m stadium approval |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=November 8, 2017}}</ref> Nashville was the first confirmed team approved by the MLS during this phase of expansion on December 20.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3318519/mls-confirms-nashville-will-be-home-to-its-latest-expansion-franchise |title=MLS confirms Nashville will be home to its latest expansion franchise |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=December 20, 2017}}</ref>
=== Austin (2021)=== {{Main|Austin FC}} On December 7, 2018, Garber announced in his annual State of the League news conference that "within the next few years MLS will become the first major sports league to have a team in the culturally dynamic city of Austin" with more details to come in the months ahead.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.statesman.com/sports/20181207/commissioner-don-garber-more-details-on-mls-in-austin-soon |title=Commissioner Don Garber: More details on MLS in Austin soon |work=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |date=December 7, 2018}}</ref>
=== St. Louis (2022)=== {{Main|St. Louis MLS team}} Jeff Cooper attempted in 2008 and 2009 to bring an MLS expansion team to [[Greater St. Louis|St. Louis]], only to have both bids turned down in favor of other cities. Despite approved stadium plans to build the $600 million [[Collinsville Soccer Complex]], MLS was not impressed with the bid's financial backing and suggested Cooper expand his group of investors.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} Cooper instead launched a second division men's club and a [[Women's Professional Soccer]] franchise. [[AC St. Louis]] played only one season in [[USSF Division 2 Professional League|Division 2]] averaging 2,750 fans during the 2010 season before folding,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.insidemnsoccer.com/2011/01/17/ac-st-louis-closes-its-doors-for-good/|title=AC St. Louis Closes its Doors for Good|last=Quarstad|first=Brian|date=January 17, 2011|work=IMS Soccer News}}</ref>{{Self-published inline|date=December 2013}} and the [[Saint Louis Athletica]] folded midway through its second season in 2010.
[[St. Louis]] announced in late 2014 that it was planning [[National Car Rental Field|a new stadium]] to host both American football and soccer.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/05/sports/football/wary-of-losing-rams-st-louis-is-set-to-huddle-on-stadium.html|title=Saint Louis is set to huddle on stadium|date=November 5, 2014|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 14, 2015}}</ref> Garber stated in January 2015 that: "St. Louis has got a lot of activity going on with a stadium that they’re trying to get done for the [[National Football League|NFL]] [[Los Angeles Rams|Rams]]". There's a big soccer community out there and we'd love to see a soccer stadium downtown like they're thinking about a football stadium.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://mlsmultiplex.com/2015/01/16/don-garber-says-mls-heading-st-louis/|title=Don Garber Says MLS Could Be Heading To St. Louis|date=January 16, 2015|work=MLS Multiplex|accessdate=January 16, 2015}}</ref>
In May 2015, Garber visited St. Louis to talk about a possible new multi-purpose stadium that would be capable of holding soccer games. Garber cautioned that any possible expansion to St. Louis would occur after 2020.<ref>[http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/05/19/mls-commissioner-don-garber-meets-st-louis-officials-discuss-future-expansion "MLS Commissioner Don Garber meets with St. Louis officials to discuss future expansion"], MLSsoccer.com, Dan Itel, May 19, 2015.</ref>
On January 12, 2016, The NFL's [[Los Angeles Rams|Rams]] relocated to Los Angeles from St. Louis and the Rams relocation initially accelerated the talks of an MLS expansion team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/01/19/mls-commissioner-don-garber-talks-st-louis-expansion-sports-illustrated|title=MLS Commissioner Don Garber talks St. Louis expansion with Sports Illustrated|work=MLSsoccer.com|accessdate=March 24, 2016}}</ref>
On January 27, 2016, St. Louis lawmaker, Keith English proposed a bill that would put a tax of not more than one-tenth of one percent on the ballot in St. Louis and [[St. Louis County, Missouri|St. Louis County]], it also calls for the RSA to oversee the soccer stadium.{{Citation needed|date=February 2016}} The proposed tax would only go into effect if MLS awards a team to St. Louis by December 20, 2020. On February 17, 2016, the MLS2STL group was formed to bring an MLS team to the [[St. Louis area]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sj-r.com/news/20160217/st-louis-group-formed-to-attract-mls-expansion-franchise|title=St. Louis group formed to attract MLS expansion franchise|date=February 17, 2016|newspaper=[[The State Journal-Register]]}}</ref>
On January 26, 2017, a funding plan for a [[St. Louis MLS stadium|soccer-specific stadium]] adjacent to Union Station in downtown St. Louis was approved by the city's Aldermanic Ways and Means Committee. The proposed bill still needed to be approved by the entire Board of Aldermen before it was brought to a public vote on the April 4, 2017, general municipal ballot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/st-louis-bid-for-soccer-team-back-in-play-after/article_e86ec674-e480-5b4e-baa7-f3119992bd19.html|title=New life emerges for St. Louis soccer stadium|last=Faulk|first=Mike|accessdate=March 17, 2017}}</ref> The public vote failed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://fox2now.com/2017/04/05/mls-stadium-measure-fails-in-st-louis/|title=MLS stadium measure fails in St. Louis|date=April 5, 2017|work=FOX2now.com|access-date=September 30, 2018}}</ref>
On September 27, 2018, the ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch'' reported that officials with the Missouri Department of Economic Development met with Major League Soccer representatives on a stadium proposal and St. Louis mayor Lyda Krewson confirmed there is a group trying to bring a team to St. Louis.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/soccer-stadium-talks-back-on-again-in-st-louis/article_d66a9e8e-1439-57be-be85-b697715d6b79.html|title=Soccer stadium talks back on in St. Louis|last=Feldt|first=Brian|work=stltoday.com|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref> Following speculation of a new ownership group and stadium proposal, on October 9, 2018, the bid was effectively re-launched, with Carolyn Kindle Betz and other members of the [[Jack C. Taylor|Taylor family]], principal owners of the [[Enterprise Holdings]] car rental company, as primary investors in the proposal. The stadium location remains the same as in the original 2016 location near Union Station.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stltoday.com/business/local/soccer-gets-another-shot-in-st-louis-as-family-that/article_f77a29a7-9a97-577e-84ea-92107ace964c.html#tracking-source=home-top-story|title=Soccer gets another shot in St. Louis as family that owns Enterprise launches bid for MLS team|last=Barker|first=Jacob|work=stltoday.com|access-date=October 9, 2018}}</ref> On November 28, 2018, the eight aldermen from the Housing, Urban Development, and Zoning Committee unanimously voted to approve the stadium plan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/st-louis-soccer-stadium-plan-approved-by-aldermanic-committee/article_62b2ef08-beee-5316-a076-f5a4b765a388.html#|title=St. Louis soccer stadium plan approved by aldermanic committee, 8-0|last=Reports|first=Staff|work=stltoday.com|access-date=November 28, 2018}}</ref> On November 30, 2018, the vote was taken to the board of aldermen and passed by 26 out of the 28.
On August 20, 2019, Garber appeared at a press conference in St. Louis to announce that the city had been granted a franchise to begin play in 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fox2now.com/2019/08/20/major-league-soccer-awards-expansion-franchise-to-st-louis-announcement-tuesday/ |title=Major League Soccer awards expansion franchise to St. Louis; announcement Tuesday |work=[[Fox-2 Now: St. Louis]] |date=August 29, 2019}}</ref>
=== Sacramento (2022) === {{Main|Sacramento Republic FC}} In December 2011, a group led by former California Assembly Speaker [[Fabian Núñez]] began exploring the possibility of landing an MLS franchise for the Sacramento area, with the suburb of Elk Grove as a possible stadium site.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kasler |first=Dale |url=http://www.sacbee.com/2011/12/14/4121137/group-exploring-major-league-soccer.html |title=Group exploring Major League Soccer franchise for Elk Grove|work=Sacramento Bee |date=December 14, 2011 |accessdate=February 22, 2012}}</ref> On March 13, 2013, the [[Elk Grove, California|Elk Grove]] city council voted unanimously to study potential sites for a soccer-specific stadium in the city that could host either an MLS or [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elkgrove.patch.com/articles/city-will-look-for-land-where-pro-soccer-stadium-could-be-built |title=City Will Look for Land Where Pro Soccer Stadium Could be Built |year=2013}}</ref>
Sacramento was granted a USL Pro team that began play in the 2014 season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/home/681229.html |title=Sacramento to Join USL PRO in 2014 |publisher=USLsoccer.com |date=December 3, 2012 |access-date=December 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926104815/http://www.uslsoccer.com/home/681229.html |archive-date=September 26, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> A group of investors, led by local business leader Warren Smith, expressed their hope to eventually convert this franchise to an MLS team. In November 2013, Smith restated his goal of having the team, christened [[Sacramento Republic FC (MLS)|Sacramento Republic FC]], ascend to MLS in 2016.<ref name="sacbee">{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2013/11/28/5952941/sacramento-soccer-franchise-has.html|title=Sacramento soccer franchise has ambitious goal|date=November 28, 2013|work=Sacramento Bee|first=Ryan|last=Lillis}}</ref>
In August 2014, owners of the [[Sacramento Kings]] NBA basketball team led by businessman [[Vivek Ranadivé]] expressed an interest in buying Republic FC with the ultimate goal of elevating the team to MLS. They met with league officials during the week of the [[2014 MLS All-Star Game]], and deputy commissioner Mark Abbott said league executives would visit the city and tour possible stadium locations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lillis|first1=Ryan|title=Major League Soccer to tour possible stadium sites in Sacramento|url=http://www.sacbee.com/2014/08/05/6607197/major-league-soccer-to-tour-possible.html|accessdate=August 6, 2014|work=Sacramento Bee|date=August 5, 2014}}</ref> Kings owner Ranadive announced in January 2015 that he had joined the Republic ownership group, in a move seen as bolstering the city's chances of landing an MLS berth.<ref name="sbisoccer.com">[http://www.sbisoccer.com/2015/01/sacramento-republic-investor.html "SACRAMENTO KINGS JOIN REPUBLIC AS INVESTOR IN MLS PUSH"], SBI Soccer, January 28, 2015.</ref> Also in January 2015, the York family, owners of the NFL's [[San Francisco 49ers]], agreed to invest in the Republic.<ref>[http://www.sacbee.com/sports/mls/article8604596.html "49ers’ owners to invest in Sacramento Republic FC"], ''Sacramento Bee'', January 29, 2015.</ref>
Sacramento's bid is also strengthened by its fan support. Upon their debut in 2014, the Republic set a USL single-game attendance record by selling out their first-ever home game at 20,000-seat [[Charles C. Hughes Stadium|Hughes Stadium]];<ref>[http://www.sacbee.com/2014/04/26/6357273/republic-fc-loses-home-opener.html "Republic FC loses home opener before sellout crowd at Hughes Stadium"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140427210131/http://www.sacbee.com/2014/04/26/6357273/republic-fc-loses-home-opener.html |date=April 27, 2014 }}, Sacramento Bee, April 27, 2014.</ref> since moving to the smaller, soccer-specific stadium now known as [[Papa Murphy's Park]] midway through 2014, the team has continued to play in front of capacity crowds. As of January 2015, the club had nearly 10,000 ticket deposits as part of its "Built for MLS" campaign.<ref name="sbisoccer.com"/>
In March 2015, Sacramento mayor [[Kevin Johnson (basketball)|Kevin Johnson]] announced a joint initiative of the city and the club dubbed "Operation Turnkey", which would have stadium construction ready to begin should one of the other expansion candidates without a firm stadium plan fail to come up with one or the league decided to expand beyond 24 teams.<ref>{{cite news | title = MLS Expansion: Sacramento eyes team despite Miami, Minnesota | work = Sports Illustrated | url = https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2015/03/17/sacramento-mls-expansion-minnesota-miami-kevin-johnson-beckham# | accessdate = March 22, 2015 | date = March 15, 2015 | first = Brian | last = Straus}}</ref>
In April 2016, MLS commissioner Don Garber announced that the league would expand to 28 teams and said "I hope, and fully expect, Sacramento to be one (of the 28)".<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/sacramento/news/2016/04/14/commissioner-we-hopeexpect-sacramento-join-mls.html "Commissioner: 'We hope and expect' Sacramento will join MLS"], April 14, 2016.</ref>
On February 4, 2017, after the official bid package was submitted without the Republic name or brand, Sacramento mayor [[Darrell Steinberg]] announced an agreement in principle for the Republic to be acquired by Sac Soccer & Entertainment Holdings, the company behind the submitted bid.<ref name="acquire17"/> Should the city's bid for an MLS expansion team succeed, it will indeed enter the league as Sacramento Republic FC.<ref name="acquire17">{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/02/05/sacramento-mls-bid-group-enters-agreement-acquire-sacramento-republic-fc|title=Sacramento MLS bid group enters agreement to acquire Sacramento Republic FC|publisher=MLSSoccer|date=February 5, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017, the group began preparations for building a 19,621-seat stadium in downtown Sacramento for the bid.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/news-columns-blogs/city-beat/article163854248.html |title=Big step in Sacramento's Major League Soccer bid |work=[[The Sacramento Bee]] |date=July 27, 2017}}</ref> By October, the group had 10,000 commitments for season tickets for the proposed MLS team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sacbee.com/sports/mls/article180795416.html |title=10,000 Sacramento fans commit to buy MLS season tickets, Republic FC reports |work=The Sacramento Bee |date=October 25, 2017}}</ref>
On January 22, 2019, billionaire [[Ron Burkle]] was announced as the Republic's new lead investor to satisfy MLS requirements. Burkle has held a controlling stake in the NHL's [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] since 1999, and previously made an attempt to buy the Sacramento Kings. Burkle also purchased the Republic's proposed stadium site at the [[Sacramento Railyards]], along with an additional 14 acres to be developed into an entertainment district.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3756895/sacramento-republics-mls-hopes-get-boost-as-ron-burkle-agrees-to-take-over-team |title=Sacramento Republic's MLS hopes get boost as Ron Burkle agrees to take over team |last=Carlisle |first=Jeff |date=January 22, 2019 |publisher=[[ESPN]] |access-date=January 22, 2019}}</ref>
On October 21, 2019, the Republic was officially announced as the 29th team in Major League Soccer, joining the league in 2022.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/10/21/major-league-soccer-awards-expansion-team-sacramento|title=Major League Soccer awards expansion team to Sacramento|date=October 21, 2019|publisher=Major League Soccer}}</ref>
== Current expansion candidates == Commissioner Don Garber stated in May 2018 that "Detroit, Sacramento, San Diego are still in active discussions with us"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wzzm13.com/article/sports/soccer/detroits-2020-mls-bid-hindered-by-choosing-ford-field/69-559824127|title=Detroit's 2020 MLS bid hindered by choosing Ford Field|work=wzzm13.com|publisher=WZZM-TV|date=May 30, 2018}}</ref> and in September 2018 "We continue to believe that with the right ownership group, stadium plan and support from the corporate community, St. Louis could be a successful Major League Soccer market."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/09/27/st-louis-mayor-prospective-owners-pursuing-mls-team|title=St. Louis mayor: Prospective owners pursuing MLS team|date=September 27, 2018}}</ref>
On April 18, 2019, the league announced it would expand to 30 teams. Ownership groups from Sacramento and St. Louis were given exclusive rights to negotiate for spots 28 and 29 at an expansion fee of $200 million each, while the league's Board of Governors deferred a decision on a fee and timetable for the 30th team. St. Louis was announced as the 28th team in August 2019, while Sacramento was announced as the 29th team on October 21 of that year.<ref name="auto"/>
=== Las Vegas === The ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'' reported on May 14, 2014, that a potential ownership group held talks about an expansion team in Las Vegas.<ref name="auto1">{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/05/14/report-las-vegas-talks-mls-bring-expansion-club-city-build-soccer-specific-s |title=Report: Las Vegas in talks with MLS to bring expansion club to city, build soccer-specific stadium |work=MLSsoccer.com |date=May 14, 2014 |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref> The investor group, consisting of Findlay Sports and Entertainment and real estate developers, [[Cordish Company]], acquired a 61-acre site at [[Symphony Park]] in [[Downtown Las Vegas]] from the city and released a plan to build a 24,000-seat stadium there.<ref name="auto2">{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2014/5/14/5718422/las-vegas-mls-expansion |title=Las Vegas launches MLS expansion bid |work=SBNation.com |accessdate=May 19, 2014}}</ref> Las Vegas Mayor, [[Carolyn Goodman (politician)|Carolyn Goodman]], and the Findlay group expressed preference for a downtown stadium.<ref name="auto3">{{cite news|last1=Snel|first1=Alan|title=City of Las Vegas turns suitor's attention toward Major League Soccer|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/city-las-vegas-turns-suitor-s-attention-toward-major-league-soccer|accessdate=June 3, 2014|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 24, 2014}}</ref> League deputy commissioner Mark Abbott visited the city in July 2014 to meet with Mayor Goodman and to tour the downtown area.<ref name="auto4">{{cite news|last1=Firchau|first1=Nick|title=Thinking long-term, MLS in "preliminary discussions" over expansion franchise in Las Vegas|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/07/21/thinking-long-term-mls-preliminary-discussions-over-expansion-franchise-las-|accessdate=August 6, 2014|work=MLSsoccer.com|date=July 22, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/lights-fc-soccer/5-things-to-know-as-las-vegas-pursues-mls-expansion-team-1689254/|title=5 things to know as Las Vegas pursues MLS expansion team|date=June 17, 2019|accessdate=June 18, 2019}}</ref>
On December 17, 2014, the Las Vegas City Council approved public funding of $56.5 million for the proposed soccer stadium in Symphony Park, contingent on MLS granting an expansion franchise to Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2014/dec/17/city-council-set-vote-las-vegas-soccer-stadium/|title=City Council approves funding for Las Vegas soccer stadium|first=Conor|last=Shine|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=December 17, 2014}}</ref>
Garber notified Las Vegas Mayor Carolyn Goodman on February 12, 2015 that MLS no longer considered Las Vegas as an expansion market until after 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/02/12/las-vegas-no-longer-consideration-mls-expansion-until-after-2018/|title=Las Vegas no longer in consideration for MLS expansion until after 2018|work=MLSsoccer.com|date=February 12, 2015}}</ref> The potential for a Las Vegas team was revived in January 2017 by the city council approaching a sports investment bank but an official bid was not reported by MLS.<ref name="12Bids">{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/12-groups-submit-mls-expansion-applications/n-5232189 |title=12 Groups Submit MLS Expansion Applications |publisher=OurSports Central |date=January 31, 2017}}</ref> On August 20, 2017, Las Vegas was awarded a [[Las Vegas Lights FC|USL expansion franchise]] to begin play at [[Cashman Field]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/822459?referrer_id=2349190|title=Las Vegas Joins the USL in 2018 Season|date=August 11, 2017|publisher=United Soccer League (USL)|accessdate=August 14, 2017}}</ref>
=== Charlotte === In 2017 [[Speedway Motorsports]] CEO [[Marcus G. Smith|Marcus Smith]] led an effort for MLS expansion to Charlotte that initially included a 20,000 to 30,000 seat stadium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twcnews.com/nc/charlotte/news/2017/01/9/charlotte-leaders-negotiating-deal-to-bid-for-major-league-soccer-team-at-memorial-stadium.html|title=Charlotte Leaders Negotiating Deal to Bid for Major League Soccer Team at Memorial Stadium|accessdate=January 11, 2017}}</ref> The Smiths' bid was not affiliated with the USL's [[Charlotte Independence]]. In October 2017, however, the Charlotte city council confirmed that they would be unable to come up with the financing needed for the MLS deadline for expansion proposals, at which point the bid was effectively dead.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/business/article180429991.html |title=Charlotte's Major League Soccer dreams are dead for now. Here's how the deal unraveled |work=[[The Charlotte Observer]] |date=October 23, 2017}}</ref>
In March 2019 [[Carolina Panthers]] owner [[David Tepper]] and officials began discussions with MLS to start another bid for a Charlotte based MLS team. After MLS announced that they would be expanding to 30 teams, the Panthers officially reactivated the bid.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/business/article229456349.html |title=Major League Soccer expands again, opening door for Charlotte and David Tepper |work=The Charlotte Observer |date=April 19, 2019}}</ref>
=== Phoenix === In 2017, [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] entered the race for an expansion team.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/mls-expansion-phoenix-cities-list-012617 |title=Phoenix set to join the race for an MLS expansion team |date=January 26, 2017}}</ref> The bid for expansion is led by the ownership group of [[Phoenix Rising FC]] of the [[United Soccer League]] including [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and Phoenix Rising FC player [[Didier Drogba]].<ref name="12Bids"/> Phoenix Rising recently signed an agreement with [[Goldman Sachs]] to help the funding of a new 20,000 person [[Phoenix MLS stadium|stadium]] on land purchased from the [[Salt River Pima–Maricopa Indian Community|Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community]] if selected.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.phxrisingfc.com/news_article/show/788390?referrer_id=2717359|title=Phoenix Rising Football Club retains Goldman Sachs as Structuring Agent for MLS Soccer Stadium|last=Communications|first=Phoenix Rising FC|date=May 3, 2017|work=Phoenix Rising FC {{!}} Arizona's Highest Level Professional Soccer Team|access-date=May 4, 2017}}</ref>
=== Indianapolis === In January 2017, Indianapolis launched an official bid to upgrade their NASL franchise, the [[Indy Eleven]], to an MLS expansion member, but their bid was not chosen.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.indystar.com/story/sports/2017/01/30/indy-eleven-apply-mls-expansion/97271092/ |title=Indy Eleven to apply for MLS expansion |date=January 30, 2017 }}</ref>
In January 10, 2019 Indy Eleven, now an USL team led by developer and owner Ersal Ozdemir of Keystone Group re-launched the talks for the stadium, now anchoring a planned neighborhood named "Eleven Park". This planned neighborhood included 150,000 square feet of office space, 100,000 square feet of retail, 600 apartment units, a 200-room boutique hotel and was anchored by a 20,000-seat multi-purpose soccer stadium. The team planned to work with [[Indiana state legislature]] to fund the project with taxes that was generated near the property of the stadium.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.indyeleven.com/news_article/show/983903|title=ICYMI {{!}} ELEVEN PARK: A TRANSFORMATIONAL NEIGHBORHOOD DEVELOPMENT FOR INDIANAPOLIS UNVEILED|last=|first=|date=January 10, 2019|website=Indy Eleven|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=September 13, 2019}}</ref>
=== Raleigh === [[File:NCFCps-084.jpg|thumb|Owner Steve Malik announces rebranding to North Carolina FC|right]] On December 6, 2016, Carolina Railhawks (later rebranded as [[North Carolina FC]]) owner Steve Malik announced a push for Raleigh's minor league team to become an MLS team,<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/857350 |title=USL Adds North Carolina FC for the 2018 Season |publisher=United Soccer League |date=November 16, 2017 |accessdate=December 7, 2017}}</ref> and build a privately funded $150 million, 22,000-seat stadium in [[Wake County, North Carolina|Wake County]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/sports/soccer/north-carolina-fc-courage/article160717454.html|title=MLS president to visit Triangle as part of North Carolina FC expansion bid. Here's how you can participate.|publisher=News and Observer|accessdate=July 13, 2017}}</ref>
On June 18, 2019, the team unveiled plans for a 20,000 seat stadium as part of a $1.9 billion mixed use development in downtown [[Raleigh]], intended to boost the MLS bid.<ref>[https://www.wralsportsfan.com/ncfc-s-malik-will-announce-1-9b-plan-for-multi-use-soccer-complex-next-week/18458998/ NCFC's Malik will announce $1.9B plan for multi-use soccer complex next week] - WRAL Sports Fan, 18 June 2019</ref>
== Failed, stalled, or speculated expansion efforts == This section includes cities with bids that have either failed or stalled, or are otherwise not explicitly included in the MLS expansion roadmap, the latest of which was announced in December 2013.<ref name="roadmap 2013"/>
=== Cleveland (2004–06) === MLS announced in 2004 that Cleveland would be getting an expansion franchise for the 2005 season, as area businessman [[Bert Wolstein]] had signed a letter of intent to launch an MLS club.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.soccertimes.com/mls/2004/may16.htm|title=Several cities vie for expansion teams as complications delay decision|date= May 16, 2004|work=Soccer Times|first=Robert|last=Wagman}}</ref> However, Wolstein ran into delays in trying to obtain public financing for a stadium, and died in 2004.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.soccertimes.com/mls/2004/may17|title=Bert Wolstein, a soccer pioneer, dies at 77|date= May 17, 2004|work=Soccer Times}}</ref> In 2006 the Wolstein Sports and Entertainment Group proposed the construction of a soccer-specific stadium for an MLS club in the Cleveland suburb of [[Macedonia, Ohio|Macedonia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/pdextra/2010/09/macedonia_planning_for_soccer.html|title=Macedonia planning for soccer|work=The Plain Dealer|date=July 21, 2007|first=Laura|last=Johnston}}</ref> However, [[Summit County, Ohio|Summit County]] voters rejected a tax to raise $104 million of the $165 million needed, environmental groups raised concerns about area wetlands, and the area was hit by the [[Great Recession]] of 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2010/09/post_353.html|title=Star Calendar print shop; a soccer stadium in Macedonia: Whatever happened to …?|date=September 20, 2010|work=The Plain Dealer}}</ref>
In March 2014, Commissioner Garber said there had not been any developments regarding MLS expansion in Cleveland since talks were held "many years ago."<ref name="March 2014"/>
=== Detroit (2011–13, 2016–18) === Triple Sports & Entertainment, a firm owned by Andreas Apostolopoulos, planned to convert the [[Pontiac Silverdome]] into a [[soccer-specific stadium]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20091116/NEWS03/91116065/|title=Canadian firm submits winning bid of $583,000 for Silverdome|date= November 16, 2009|work=Detroit Free Press|first=Melanie|last=Scott}}</ref> and applied to MLS for an expansion franchise in June 2011, but without success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2011/06/08/Franchises/MLS-Detroit.aspx |title=Silverdome Owners Submit Application To MLS in Hopes of Landing Franchise – SportsBusiness Daily | SportsBusiness Journal |work=SportsBusiness Daily |date=June 8, 2011|accessdate=February 22, 2012}}</ref> The company later submitted plans in July 2013 for the site that is being considered for the current Detroit expansion proposal, but was again unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20130724/NEWS/130729936/silverdome-owners-pitch-plan-for-mls-stadium-mall-condos-on-jail-site/ |title=Silverdome owners pitch plan for MLS stadium, mall, condos on jail site | Crain's Detroit Business |publisher=Crains Detroit |accessdate=September 12, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20131029/NEWS/131029799/wayne-co-committee-recommends-gilbert-bid-for-jail-site/ |title=Wayne Co. committee recommends Gilbert bid for jail site |publisher=Crains Detroit |accessdate=July 22, 2014}}</ref>
NBA owners [[Dan Gilbert]] and [[Tom Gores]] unveiled in April 2016 a $1 billion plan to bring an MLS expansion team to Detroit.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sipple|first1=George|title=Soccer mogul Roger Faulkner backs Detroit MLS plan|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/2016/04/30/soccer-roger-faulkner-detroit-mls/83774178/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=April 30, 2016|accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref> MLS Commissioner Don Garber has said that Detroit is on the list of cities that could get an expansion team in 2020, and has stated that MLS' interest in Detroit hinges on the fate of the 15-acre site of the stalled Wayne County jail development, which can connect the Greektown Entertainment District, Eastern Market and the three other sports facilities – [[Comerica Park]], [[Ford Field]], and [[Little Caesars Arena]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=George|first1=Sipple|title=Detroit's Major League Soccer expansion bid hinges on failed jail site|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/2016/04/27/detroit-mls-major-league-soccer/83607532/|website=Detroit Free Press|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref> Their plan received a boost at the end of July when Wayne County Executive Warren Evans announced that he had instructed his team to work towards a final deal on moving the jail and allowing Gilbert and Gores to build the stadium.<ref>{{cite web|title=Detroit plan that would allow for MLS stadium backed by county executive|url=http://www.espnfc.com/major-league-soccer/story/3169786/detroit-plan-that-would-allow-for-mls-stadium-backed-by-county-executive|publisher=ESPN|date=July 31, 2017|accessdate=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
Detroit was considered by MLS to be one of the frontrunners for a 2020 bid, but MLS soured on Detroit when the ownership group decided not to build a soccer-specific stadium and to use Ford Field instead.<ref>[http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20180529/news/662121/detroit-bid-in-limbo-after-mls-awards-latest-expansion-club-to "Detroit bid in limbo after MLS awards latest expansion club to Cincinnati"], Crain's Detroit Business, May 29, 2018.</ref>
=== Miami (2008–09) === A [[Miami]] expansion team led by [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[Marcelo Claure]], a Bolivian businessman based in the city, announced an expansion bid in October 2008, with plans to begin play in [[2011 Major League Soccer season|2011]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://espnfc.com/print?id=581958&type=story|title=Barcelona to bid for Miami MLS franchise|date=October 15, 2008|work=ESPNsoccernet|accessdate=February 8, 2014}}</ref> But in March 2009, the league and Barcelona announced that Miami was no longer a candidate due to local market conditions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/1110/major-league-soccer/2009/03/03/1137156/miami-barcelona-mls-campaign-is-dead|title=Miami Barcelona MLS Campaign Is Dead|work=Goal.com|date=March 3, 2009}}</ref> Additionally, MLS expressed concerns about Miami's lack of fan interest in an MLS franchise, the fact that [[United Soccer Leagues|USL]] team [[Miami FC (2006)|Miami FC]] was not doing well, and the plan to use [[FIU Stadium]] relegating the team to a secondary tenant in a [[college football]] stadium with an artificial surface.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2009-03-04/sports/0903030502_1_fc-barcelona-mls-garber|title=Miami bid is yanked|date= March 4, 2009|work=Sun-Sentinel|first=Jeff|last=Rusnak}}</ref> However, Garber said that Miami would be an expansion target in the future.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2009-03-08/sports/0903070054_1_mls-cup-garber-mls-team|title=MLS, Miami have miles to go before new club could thrive|date= March 8, 2009|work=Sun-Sentinel|first=Jeff|last=Rusnak}}</ref> Claure later joined [[David Beckham]]'s group of investors for the [[Inter Miami CF|Miami expansion bid]] that was accepted by the league in 2014.
=== San Antonio (2011–17) === A previous San Antonio expansion bid ended in 2005, when negotiations between the league and then-mayor [[Edward D. Garza|Ed Garza]] ended. Incoming mayor [[Phil Hardberger]] criticized the proposed deal, while Garber claimed that the criticisms were politically motivated and hurt efforts to sell season tickets and recruit local investors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/mls/2005-06-09-san-antonio_x.htm |title=Major League Soccer ends talks with San Antonio |agency=Associated Press |date=June 9, 2005 |accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref>
In late 2011, San Antonio announced its bid to be MLS's 20th team.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://aol.sportingnews.com/soccer/story/2011-12-14/sacramento-san-antonio-join-fight-for-mls-expansion-team |title=San Antonio joins fight for MLS expansion team |work=Sporting News |date=December 14, 2011 |accessdate=October 25, 2012}}</ref> The city's [[North American Soccer League]] franchise, the [[San Antonio Scorpions]], launched in 2012 and led the league in attendance in 2012 and 2013 seasons.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2012/09/28/Research-and-Ratings/NASL-attendance.aspx|title=NASL Attendance Up 1.1%; San Antonio Scorpions Lead League in Debut Season|date= September 28, 2012|work=Sports Business Daily}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanantonioscorpions.com/stadium/toyota-field |title=San Antonio Scorpions Toyota Field |publisher=San Antonio Scorpions |date=October 25, 2012 |accessdate=October 25, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107213036/http://sanantonioscorpions.com/stadium/toyota-field |archive-date=November 7, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In Commissioner Garber's December 2013 State of the League address, San Antonio was one of five cities listed on a presentation map of potential expansion locations.<ref name="roadmap 2013">{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/soccer/2013/12/3/5171460/mls-five-candidiate-cities-expansion |title=MLS names five candidiate cities for expansion|first=Jeremiah|last=Oshan |work=SBNation.com |date=December 3, 2013 |accessdate=February 4, 2014}}</ref> In March 2014, Garber said that expansion in the immediate future was "premature" for both San Antonio and Texas, though it was "something that is likely to happen".<ref name="March 2014">{{cite news|url=http://soccer.si.com/2014/03/04/location-by-location-mls-commissioner-don-garbers-response-to-expansion-questions/|title=Location by location, MLS commissioner Don Garber's response to expansion questions|work=Planet Fútbol|first=Avi|last=Creditor|date=March 4, 2014}}</ref>
In December 2014, Garber stated that the league was continuing to evaluate and receive updates on developments in San Antonio.<ref>[http://www.mysanantonio.com/sports/article/MLS-officials-provide-update-on-city-s-5940924.php "MLS officials provide update on city’s development for expansion"], San Antonio Express-News, December 7, 2014.</ref> Potential developments include the emergence of an outside investment group<ref>[http://www.mysanantonio.com/sports/scorpions/article/Investors-detail-plan-to-buy-Scorpions-with-MLS-5868769.php "Investors detail plan to buy Scorpions, with MLS goal"], San Antonio Express-News, November 4, 2014.</ref> and the expansion plan of the current North American Soccer League stadium.<ref>[http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/09/02/san-antonio-scorpions-release-stadium-expansion-plan-additional-opportunitie "San Antonio Scorpions release stadium expansion plan with 'additional opportunities' like MLS entry in mind"], MLSsoccer.com, September 2, 2014.</ref> In early December 2014, Garber revealed that San Antonio was "not as far along" as the three other cities under consideration at the time.<ref>[http://www.woai.com/articles/woai-local-news-sponsored-by-five-119078/scorpions-owner-san-antonio-made-the-13050933/ "Scorpions Owner: San Antonio 'Made the Cut' for Big League Consideration"], WOAI, December 10, 2014.</ref> But the league continues to monitor progress and efforts toward expansion in San Antonio.<ref name="Louis 2015">[http://prosoccertalk.nbcsports.com/2015/01/16/mls-expansion-st-louis-san-antonio-join-race-with-minneapolis-sacramento-las-vegas/ "MLS expansion: St. Louis, San Antonio join race with Minneapolis, Sacramento, Las Vegas"], ProSoccerTalk, January 16, 2015.</ref>
On November 4, 2015, the city of San Antonio and [[Bexar County, Texas|Bexar County]] announced plans to purchase Toyota Field for $18 million with the intentions of acquiring an MLS franchise. Additionally, [[Spurs Sports & Entertainment]], owners of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]'s [[San Antonio Spurs]], would hold a 20-year lease to operate the stadium; if SS&E fails to secure an MLS franchise for the stadium within 10 years, the group would owe the city and county a $5 million penalty.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bailey|first1=W. Scott|title=Spurs, city and county strike a deal for Toyota Field; MLS team part of the long-term plan|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanantonio/news/2015/11/04/spurs-city-and-county-strike-a-deal-for-toyota.html?ana=twt|work=San Antonio Business Journal|accessdate=November 5, 2015}}</ref> On December 22, 2015, the USL announced that Spurs Sports & Entertainment would operate the league's 31st team, [[San Antonio FC]]. The establishment of the club, along with the concurrent purchase of Toyota Field by the city of San Antonio and Bexar County, is part of a plan by local officials to obtain an expansion franchise in Major League Soccer. As a result, the Scorpions franchise was shut down.
On October 16, 2017, [[Columbus Crew]] owner Anthony Precourt announced his intentions of moving his club to [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] in 2019 if a new stadium in downtown Columbus is not built. As downtown Austin is approximately {{convert|75|mi|km|-1}} north of downtown San Antonio, the proposed relocation would be in direct conflict with expansion efforts in San Antonio.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stacy|first1=Mitch|title=MLS team may move to Austin, could ruin SA's chances of landing team|url=https://www.ksat.com/sports/mls-team-may-move-to-austin-could-ruin-sas-chances-of-landing-team|publisher=KSAT-TV|accessdate=November 1, 2017}}</ref> However, [[Jimmy Haslam]], owner of the NFL's [[Cleveland Browns]], and Pete Edwards, Jr. acquired the Crew in order to keep the club in Columbus and Precourt was granted rights to an expansion franchise in Austin.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cleveland Browns owners emerge as potential buyers of Columbus Crew SC|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/10/12/cleveland-browns-owners-emerge-potential-buyers-columbus-crew-sc|website=MLSSoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital|date=October 12, 2018|accessdate=October 13, 2018}}</ref>
=== San Diego (2016–18) === Commissioner Garber mentioned San Diego as an expansion candidate in February 2014,<ref name="mlssoccer.com"/> and again in April 2016.<ref name="Commissioner Garber 2016"/> The ownership group includes MLB [[San Diego Padres]] owner Peter Seidler.<ref>[http://www.espnfc.us/major-league-soccer/story/2901235/san-diego-padres-owner-among-those-interested-in-mls-franchise "San Diego Padres owner among those interested in MLS franchise"], ESPN FC, June 24, 2016.</ref> An MLS team in San Diego would be located close to two MLS teams in Los Angeles, as well as the Liga MX side Xolos of Tijuana.<ref>[http://www.espnfc.us/major-league-soccer/19/blog/post/2859611/talking-points-which-cities-will-major-league-soccer-expand-to-next "Talking Points: Which cities will Major League Soccer expand to next?"], ESPN FC, April 28, 2016.</ref> The NFL's [[Los Angeles Chargers|Chargers]] 2017 relocation to Los Angeles has accelerated the chances for an MLS expansion team in San Diego.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2017/01/12/chargers-san-diego-la-relocation-galaxy-stub-hub-center-mls-expansion|title=How does the Chargers move to LA impact MLS?|first=Avi|last=Creditor|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/01/14/mls-commissioner-don-garber-sees-expansion-opportunity-san-diego|title=MLS Commissioner Don Garber sees expansion opportunity in San Diego|date=January 14, 2017|accessdate=November 3, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/major-league-soccer/story/3038118/mls-commissioner-don-garber-hopeful-over-st-louis-san-diego-and-miami-expansion|title=MLS chief Don Garber still hopeful on St. Louis, San Diego, Miami expansion|accessdate=January 19, 2017}}</ref>
On February 20, 2017, a new plan for the Mission Valley site of the facility then known as [[Qualcomm Stadium]] was unveiled by a La Jolla investment group that's trying to lure a Major League Soccer team to San Diego.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/34545817/san-diego-investment-group-unveils-new-qualcomm-stadium-proposal|title=San Diego investment group unveils new Qualcomm stadium proposal|publisher=CBS|date=February 20, 2017}}</ref> The former [[LA Galaxy]] striker [[Landon Donovan]] joined the San Diego ownership group on March 3, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Landon Donovan joins ownership group trying to bring MLS expansion team to San Diego. {{!}} Fox Sports|url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/landon-donovan-owner-san-diego-mls-expansion-030317|publisher=Fox Sports|date=March 3, 2017}}</ref> Garber reported in May 2018 that MLS remained in active discussions with San Diego.
On June 20, 2019, [[Landon Donovan]] was awarded a [[USL San Diego|USL expansion franchise]] in [[San Diego]] to begin play at [[Torero Stadium]] in 2020 or 2021.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2019/06/19/usl-san-diego-landon-donovan-warren-smith|title=Landon Donovan, Warren Smith bring USL to San Diego|website=SI.com|language=en|access-date=2019-06-20}}</ref>
=== Tampa Bay (2016–17) ===
In December 2016, MLS confirmed that Tampa / St. Petersburg was one of its ten potential expansion cities. [[Bill Edwards (businessman)|Bill Edwards]], the majority owner of the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies]] started a campaign to join the league.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/major-league-soccer-announces-tampa-bay-rowdies-as-potential-expansion-team/n-5222501 |title=Major League Soccer Announces Tampa Bay Rowdies as Potential Expansion Team |publisher=OurSports Central |date=December 15, 2016}}</ref> On May 2, 2017, a special election referendum was held in St. Petersburg to vote on the city negotiating a 25-year land lease for the Tampa Bay Rowdies current waterfront Al Lang Stadium and increasing capacity to 18,000 pending MLS expansion acceptance. The vote was 87% in favor of Al Lang Stadium redesign/expansion, and 13% against.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/localgovernment/tampa-bay-rowdies-major-league-soccer-hopes-rest-with-st-petersburg-voters/2322337|title=St. Petersburg voters overwhelmingly bless Tampa Bay Rowdies' bid to join Major League Soccer|website=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=May 3, 2017}}</ref>
=== Other efforts === [[Rochester, New York]], had been mentioned as an expansion candidate due to the success of the [[Rochester Rhinos]]. The Rhinos won the [[US Open Cup]] in 1999 – the only non-MLS team to win the Cup since MLS began play three years earlier – and the Rhinos averaged over 10,000 fans from 1999 to 2005.<ref>[http://www.soccernewsday.com/usa/a/170/the-lost-soccer-city-of-rochester The Lost Soccer City of Rochester] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310080001/http://soccernewsday.com/usa/a/170/the-lost-soccer-city-of-rochester |date=March 10, 2016 }}, Soccer Newsday, June 19, 2012.</ref> In 2006, Don Garber stated: "At some point we want to find a way we can have an MLS team in Rochester."<ref name="democratandchronicle1">{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/article/20110612/SPORTS05/106120356/Rochester-Rhinos-no-longer-MLS-radar|title=High School Sports – Democrat and Chronicle – democratandchronicle.com|work=Democrat and Chronicle|accessdate=December 11, 2014}}</ref> However, the Rhinos saw a downturn in attendance and finances, and the city is no longer under consideration by MLS.<ref name="democratandchronicle1"/>
Throughout late 2008 and early 2009, [[Ottawa]] was a longshot candidate for one of two slots for MLS expansion,<ref>[http://www.soccerbyives.net/2008/10/mls-expansion-c.html "SEVEN MLS EXPANSION CANDIDATES REVEALED"], Soccer By Ives, October 15, 2008. Retrieved March 27, 2014.</ref> but the push ended in March 2009 when MLS selected Vancouver and Portland instead.<ref>Soccer By Ives, [http://www.soccerbyives.net/2009/03/vancouver-to-be-introduced-as-17th-mls-team.html VANCOUVER TO BE INTRODUCED AS 17TH MLS TEAM], March 18, 2009. Retrieved March 21, 2014.</ref> On June 20, 2011, Ottawa was awarded a NASL expansion franchise which began play as [[Ottawa Fury FC]] at [[TD Place Stadium]] in 2014; Fury FC moved to USL after the 2016 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/oseg-backs-winner-with-ottawa-fury-fc-move-to-usl-1.3824164 |title=OSEG backs winner with Fury FC move to USL |first=Mario |last=Cariucci |publisher=[[CBC News]] |date=October 29, 2016 |accessdate=December 7, 2017}}</ref>
MLS announced in May 2010 the league's desire for a second franchise in New York. The [[New York Cosmos (1971–85)|New York Cosmos]] expressed interest in an MLS expansion franchise, but negotiations between MLS and the Cosmos broke down,<ref name="cosmos_return">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/02/sports/soccer/02cosmos.html |title=Cosmos Begin Anew, With Eye Toward M.L.S|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 1, 2010 |accessdate=May 22, 2013 | first=Jack | last=Bell}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/03/sports/soccer/reborn-cosmos-return-to-the-field.html?pagewanted=all|title= Reborn Cosmos Return to the Field|date=August 2, 2013|first=Jack|last=Bell|work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 28, 2014}}</ref> and the [[New York Cosmos (2010)|new Cosmos]] began playing in the [[North American Soccer League]] in 2013.<ref name=joinnasl2013>{{cite web|first=Seamus|last=O'Brien|url=http://nycosmos.com/news/new-york-cosmos-join-nasl-2013|title=New York Cosmos Returns to NASL|location=New York City|work=nycosmos.com|publisher=New York Cosmos|date=July 12, 2012|accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> The league also met with other prospective ownership groups for a New York expansion team.<ref name="Straus 2011">{{cite news|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/soccer/story/2011-10-26/chuck-blazer-group-emerges-to-rival-cosmos-bid-for-mls-team-in-new-york-city|title= Rival emerges in Cosmos' bid to land MLS expansion team|date=October 26, 2011|first=Brian|last=Straus|work=Sporting News|accessdate=April 28, 2014}}</ref> For example, MLS held talks with [[New York Mets]] owner [[Fred Wilpon]].<ref name="Sports.espn.go.com"/><ref name="cosmos_return"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/mls-focused-making-ny-club-its-20th-team |title=MLS focused on making NY club its 20th team |date=November 16, 2010|work=mlssoccer.com|accessdate=May 21, 2013}}</ref> MLS awarded the second New York franchise to [[New York City FC]] in May 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2013/05/21/with-new-york-city-fc-does-mls-still-have-room-for-the-cosmos/ |title=With New York City FC, Does MLS Have Room for the Cosmos? |last1=Bercovici |first1=Jeff |date=May 21, 2013 |work=Forbes |accessdate=May 22, 2013}}</ref> Garber confirmed in April 2014 that there would not be a third New York team after the [[New York Red Bulls]] and New York City FC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AndrewDasNYT/status/459698113322975232 |title=Twitter / AndrewDasNYT: Garber says @NYCosmos aren't |publisher=Twitter |accessdate=April 28, 2014}}</ref>
