{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=December 2017}} {{advert|date=December 2017}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Soccer United Marketing | logo = Soccer United Marketing logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | type = Private | area_served = North America | key_people = [[Don Garber]], Chief Executive Officer

[[Russell Findlay]], Chief Marketing Officer

Will Wilson, Executive Vice President

[[Sunil Gulati]], Board of Directors | industry = [[Advertising]], [[Marketing]], [[Sports]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = [[Major League Soccer]] | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | foundation = {{start date and age|2002}} | location_city = | location_country = | location = | locations = | slogan = | homepage = [http://www.sumworld.com Official website] | dissolved = }} '''Soccer United Marketing''' is the for-profit marketing arm of [[Major League Soccer]] and the exclusive marketing partner of the [[United States Soccer Federation]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/advertise|title=MLS DIGITAL PROPERTIES & SOCCER UNITED MARKETING|last=|first=|date=2016-12-05|website=mlssoccer.com|publisher=MLS Digital|access-date=2016-12-05}} which primarily both deal in the promotion and sanctioning of professional [[Association football|soccer]] in the [[United States]].{{Cite web|url=http://conmebol.com/en/12022015-1202/concacaf-and-conmebol-award-img-and-soccer-united-marketing-copa-america-centenario|title=CONCACAF and CONMEBOL Award IMG and Soccer United Marketing Copa America Centenario 2016 Commercial Rights {{!}} Conmebol.com|website=conmebol.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} As well, in 2016, Soccer United Marketing was chosen as the exclusive worldwide marketing partner of [[CONCACAF]] and [[CONMEBOL]]. [[CONMEBOL]] describes Soccer United Marketing as "the preeminent commercial soccer enterprise in North America, overseeing the marketing, promotion and operational execution of the region’s most successful soccer entities."{{Cite web|url=http://conmebol.com/en/12022015-1202/concacaf-and-conmebol-award-img-and-soccer-united-marketing-copa-america-centenario|title=CONCACAF and CONMEBOL Award IMG and Soccer United Marketing Copa America Centenario 2016 Commercial Rights {{!}} Conmebol.com|website=conmebol.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} [[CONMEBOL|It]] goes on to describe Soccer United Marketing as the business that "holds the exclusive commercial rights to [[Major League Soccer]] and the [[United States Soccer Federation]], as well as promotional, operational and marketing rights to [[Mexico national football team]] games played in the United States."{{Cite web|url=http://conmebol.com/en/12022015-1202/concacaf-and-conmebol-award-img-and-soccer-united-marketing-copa-america-centenario|title=CONCACAF and CONMEBOL Award IMG and Soccer United Marketing Copa America Centenario 2016 Commercial Rights {{!}} Conmebol.com|website=conmebol.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} Soccer United Marketing has also assisted in the organization of several international soccer events with North American involvement, including the [[North American SuperLiga]], the [[Pan-Pacific Championship]], and the [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]]. ==Affiliations with United States Soccer Federation and its Leadership== [[Roger A. Pielke, Jr.]], a noted author, professor, and chair of the Sports Governance Center in the Department of Athletics at the [[University of Colorado Boulder]], confirms that Soccer United Marketing, as the marketing arm of Major League Soccer, is affiliated with the [[United States Soccer Federation]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccernomics-agency.com/?p=973|title=Soccernomics Agency: Consultancy, Research, Ideas » US Soccer and Conflicts of Interest|website=www.soccernomics-agency.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} Regarding the relationship between Soccer United Marketing and United States Soccer Federation, Roger A. Pielke, Jr. writes that the United States Soccer Federation "exempts from its conflict of interest policy 'any constituent or affiliated member entities of U.S. Soccer'”, which includes Major League Soccer and Soccer United Marketing.{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccernomics-agency.com/?p=973|title=Soccernomics Agency: Consultancy, Research, Ideas » US Soccer and Conflicts of Interest|website=www.soccernomics-agency.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} [[Roger A. Pielke, Jr.]] writes, sourcing the New York Daily news, that this conflict of interest exemption allowed [[Sunil Gulati]] to become President of the United States Soccer Federation while also being a "founder, board member, and deputy commissioner of Major League Soccer, and a member of Soccer United Marketing's Board of Directors.{{Cite web|url=http://www.soccernomics-agency.com/?p=973|title=Soccernomics Agency: Consultancy, Research, Ideas » US Soccer and Conflicts of Interest|website=www.soccernomics-agency.com|access-date=2016-12-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://interactive.nydailynews.com/2016/03/how-us-soccer-mistreats-world-cup-winning-womens-national-team/|title=How US Soccer mistreats World Cup-winning Women’s National Team|website=interactive.nydailynews.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} Describing the relationship between Major League Soccer and the United States Soccer Federation, MLS Commissioner and Soccer United Marketing CEO Don Garber told [[Sports Illustrated]], " [[Sunil Gulati|Sunil]] and Dan (Flynn) had this view that as the governing body of the sport they would make commitments on the commercial side and on the competitive side to have MLS be the leader of the sport." He continued to say, "That’s not something that exists in other parts of the world. I believe that [[Sunil Gulati|Sunil]] could have made a different decision when he came in as president (in 2006), and had he made that decision MLS isn’t what it is today. Because we are joined at the hip.” Similarly describing the relationship between Soccer United Marketing and the United States Soccer Federation, USSF President [[Sunil Gulati]] said, "The growth of the game goes hand in hand with what the league has done over the last 16 years and the growth of so much of what’s going on in U.S. Soccer. The working relationship between the two is extraordinary and my guess is there aren’t many in the world that are like that. We don’t have the sorts of conflicts you see between leagues and federations – that’s a plus.”{{Cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2013/06/07/sunil-gulatis-steady-rise-biggest-challenge-still-come-word|title=Sunil Gulati's steady rise, with the biggest challenge still to come|last=Boehm|first=Charles|date=2016-06-07|website=mlssoccer.com|publisher=Major League Soccer|access-date=2016-12-05}} Soccer United Marketing and the United States Soccer Federation have played a key role in cementing Major League Soccer as the first division of professional closed-league soccer in America, which the Professional Council of United States Soccer Federation describes as "a unique ownership and operating structure, based on a 'single entity' concept." The Professional Council goes on to explain that "MLS' 'single entity' structure allows investors to own an interest in the league, as well as individual teams."{{Cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/about/affiliates/professional-soccer|title=Professional Council|website=www.ussoccer.com|access-date=2016-12-05}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sumworld.com/ Official website] [[Category:Major League Soccer]] [[Category:Marketing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Marketing companies established in 2002]] [[Category:Sports companies]]

'''Major League Soccer First Kick''' is an opening match of a [[MLS]] season. Since 2008, it has aired on [[ESPN2]].
== First Kick 2008 == First Kick 2008 was played on March 29. This game featured the [[New England Revolution]] and the [[Houston Dynamo]], which was a rematch of the previous years MLS Cup. They played in [[Foxborough, Massachusetts]], at [[Gillette Stadium]]. It was a special game for New England because they had never had a home opener on home turf. New England won with a score of 3-0.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.houstondynamo.com/news/2008/03/dynamo-0-new-england-revolution-3 | title=Dynamo 0, New England Revolution 3 | publisher=Houton Dynamo | date=March 29, 2008 | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> Goals were scored for New England by [[Steve Ralston|Ralston]] in the 16th minute, [[Adam Cristman|Cristman]] in the 32nd minute and [[Sainey Nyassi|Nyassi]] in additional time around the 93rd minute.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.revolutionsoccer.net/schedule?month=all&year=2008&competition_type=all&broadcast_type=all&op=Search&form_build_id=form-d97b813b3f1202d74a64d8851408684b&form_id=mls_schedule_form | title=All Competition Types - 2008 | publisher=New England Revolution | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3590015 | title=Revolution Launches 2008 "Countdown to First Kick" Tour | publisher=Our Sports Central | date=February 7, 2008 | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== First Kick 2009 == First Kick 2009 was played on March 19. This game featured the [[Seattle Sounders]] FC and the [[New York Red Bulls]]. They played in Seattle Washington, at Xbox Pitch at Qwest Field. This was a special game for the Seattle because it was the first regular season game ever. Seattle won the game 3-0 with goals scored in the 12th minute by [[Fredy Montero|Montero]], 25th minute by [[Brad Evans|Evans]] and in the 75th minute again by Montero.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soundersfc.com/matchday/schedule.aspx?y=2009 | title=Schedule - 2009 | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soundersfc.com/matchday/matches/2009/season/game-1-vs-new-york.aspx | title=New York Red Bulls | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== First Kick 2010 == First Kick 2010 was played on March 25. This game featured the Seattle Sounders FC and the [[Philadelphia Union]]. They played in Seattle Washington, at Xbox Pitch at Qwest Field. Seattle won the game with a score of 2-0. Goals were scored in the 12th minute by Evans and in the 43rd minute by Montero.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soundersfc.com/matchday/schedule.aspx?y=2010 | title=Schedule - 2010 | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soundersfc.com/matchday/matches/2010/season/game-01-vs-philadelphia.aspx | title=Philadelphia Union | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== First Kick 2011 == First Kick 2011 was played on March 15. This game featured the Seattle Sounders FC and the [[LA Galaxy]]. They played in Seattle Washington, at Xbox Pitch at Quest Field. The LA Galaxy went away with the win with a score of 1-0. [[Vitor Gomes Pereira Junior|Juninho]] scored in the 58th minute for the Galaxy.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lagalaxy.com/schedule?month=all&year=2011&competition_type=all&broadcast_type=all&op=Search&form_build_id=form-588a0c494b45e9e52881677795c0d0ab&form_id=mls_schedule_form | title=All Competition Types - 2011 | publisher=LA Galaxy | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soundersfc.com/matchday/matches/2011/season/mls-01-vs-galaxy.aspx | title=MLS First Kick | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== First Kick 2012 == First Kick 2012 was played on March 12. This game featured the Philadelphia Union and the [[Portland Timbers]]. They played in Portland Oregon, at JELD-WEN Field. The Portland Timbers won the game 3-1 even though Philadelphia scored first. Philadelphia's lone goal was scored by [[Gabriel Enrique Gómez|Gomez]] in the 51st minute. Portland answered right away with goals in the 54th minute by [[Andrew Jean-Baptiste|Baptiste]], 66th minute by [[Kris Boyd|Boyd]] and 76th minute by [[Kalif Alhassan|Alhassan]]. This was the most goals scored in any of the First Kick games.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.philadelphiaunion.com/news/2012/03/recap-union-fall-portland-3-1-open-12-season | title=Recap: Union fall in Portland, 3-1, to open '12 season | publisher=Philadelphia Union | date=March 13, 2012 | accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref>
== First Kick 2013 == First Kick 2013 is still being determined.

{{Infobox football league | name = MLS Reserve League | logo = | pixels = | country = United States
Canada | founded = 2005 | folded = 2014 | divisions = | teams = | relegation = | levels = | champions = [[Chicago Fire Reserves]] | season = }} The '''MLS Reserve League''' was a [[association football|soccer]] league for the [[reserve team]]s of [[Major League Soccer]] with teams in both the United States and Canada. It was inaugurated on April 9, 2005, with the first official reserve game being a 2–0 victory by [[Chivas USA]] over the host [[San Jose Earthquakes]]. The reserve division disbanded after the 2008 season, but returned in 2011 with 18 clubs split into East, Central, and West divisions.[http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/commissioner-reveals-details-reserve-division Commissioner reveals details of Reserve Division] Each club played ten games consisting of home-and-away matches versus each of its five divisional opponents. In 2013, the schedule of the MLS Reserve League was integrated with the schedule of the [[USL Pro]], with teams from each league playing each other. ==Format== ===2005–2008=== * Each MLS franchise fielded a reserve division team and played a 12-game schedule (six home, six away). All teams played a minimum of seven opposing reserve division teams at least once throughout the year. The reserve division standings consisted of a single table with the team that finished in first place at the end of the regular season earning the title of reserve division champions and a $20,000 team bonus. * A total of 20 eligible players for the home team and 20 players for the visiting team could be placed on a club's game roster for any Reserve Division game with each team permitted to make up to six substitutions. * Suspensions attributable to yellow and red cards issued in Reserve Division games would only be imposed for future Reserve Division matches and not for games during the MLS regular season. Similarly, suspensions attributable to yellow and red cards issued during MLS regular season games would not apply to Reserve Division matches. * Any player who received four yellow cards during the Reserve Division season would be suspended from the next Reserve Division game in which he could appear. * No player could play more than 120 minutes in a Reserve Team match and any preceding match(es) that occur within a 60-hour period. Injury time is not considered a part of a player's maximum number of minutes played (e.g., if a player enters a game at halftime and the referee adds 2 minutes of stoppage time to the end of the second half, the player will be considered to have played 45 minutes since the 2 minutes of stoppage time is essentially added to make up for 'lost' time). * A Reserve Division call-up or "Guest Player" with an MLS team could be eligible to appear in an MLS Reserve Division Game provided that he is properly registered with U.S. Soccer. ===2011–12=== * Teams face all but two conference opponents once at home and once away. The two matches with a USL Pro side count towards the 14 match season, therefore removing two games with MLS reserve sides. * Teams may at their discretion schedule additional exhibition games for their reserve squads against non-MLS opponents. * At the conclusion of the Reserve League season, the team with the most points out of all three conferences will be determined the Reserve League Champion. * All players appearing on an MLS club's roster may represent their team in MLS Reserve League play; however, no player may play more than 120 minutes in a reserve team match and any preceding matches that occur within a sixty-hour period. Further, no player may play more than a combined total of 90 minutes in a Reserve Team Match and any preceding matches that occurred within 36 hours prior to such reserve team match. * Clubs may also use up to five academy players per reserve game. * A Reserve League call-up or "Trialist Player" with a club may appear in reserve league games provided that he is properly registered with US Soccer. A representative from the MLS Club must also certify that the trialist is a bona fide professional soccer player. Trialists may participate in a maximum of two games per club per season. * Clubs may play up to a maximum of five non-MLS Roster players per Reserve League Game. Within the five non-MLS roster player limit, only three players may be trialist players. ===2013=== In early 2013, USL and MLS reached an agreement to integrate [[USL Pro|USL]] league competition with MLS Reserves to increase the amount of exposure to real game situations by MLS team members who do not get much time in MLS competitions or provide a USL team at which future MLS players can develop. This multi-year deal is expected to lead to more games for both MLS Reserves and USL Pro teams.{{cite news| url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/01/23/mls-usl-pro-reach-deal-restructured-reserve-league| title=MLS, USL Pro reach deal on restructured Reserve League| publisher=www.mlssoccer.com| date=January 23, 2013| accessdate=January 27, 2013}} MLS Reserve teams compiled a 6 Win, 9 Tie and 11 Loss record against USL Pro Teams in 2013.{{cite news| url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/scripts/runisa.dll?M2.66006:gp:440822.972:72011+Elements/Display+E+47107+++++58092584+++786095+Y| title=USL Pro 2013 Schedule| publisher=United Soccer Leagues (USL)| date=September 8, 2013| accessdate=October 21, 2013}}{{cite news| url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/2014-reserve-league-schedule| title=2014 Reserve League Schedule| publisher=www.mlssoccer.com| date=March 8, 2014| accessdate=March 8, 2014}} ===2014=== 2014 was the final Reserve League season. Starting in 2015, MLS clubs must either affiliate with a USL Pro club or create their own team in the USL Pro. The LA Galaxy Reserve Team joined USL Pro as the [[LA Galaxy II]] in 2014 and finished third. MLS Reserve teams compiled a 9 Win, 5 Tie and 14 Loss record against USL Pro teams in 2014. ==Past Winners== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Season ! Winners ! Runners-up |- | 2005 | [[D.C. {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use American English|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Professional Referee Organization (PRO) | image = Professional Referee Organization official logo.jpg | area_served = [[United States]] and [[Canada]] | hq_location = 420 Fifth Avenue
7th Floor
New York
NY 10018{{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/contact-pro|title=Headquarters}} | key_people = Nick Primavera
([[Chief operating officer|COO]])

[[Howard Webb]]
([[General manager|General Manager]]){{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/roster/support-staff|title=Key people}} | founded = November 2012 | website = [http://www.proreferees.com Professional Referee Organization] }} {{multiple image |align = right |direction = vertical |image1 = Howard Webb march11.jpg |width1 = 225 |caption1 = [[Howard Webb]] }} '''Professional Referee Organization''' ('''PRO''') is the organization responsible for managing the [[referee (association football)|referee]] and [[assistant referee (association football)|assistant referee]] program in professional [[association football|soccer]] leagues in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], working alongside the [[United States Soccer Federation]], [[Major League Soccer]], the [[Canadian Soccer Association]], the [[North American Soccer League]], the [[United Soccer League]], the [[National Women's Soccer League]], and the [[U.S. Open Cup|Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]]. The organization’s targets are to increase the quality of officiating in U.S. and Canadian professional leagues, develop more professional-quality officials at a younger age, and produce officials who will represent the United States and Canada in [[FIFA]] competitions.{{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/about-pro/|title=About PRO}} ==History== The [[United States Soccer Federation|U.S. Soccer Federation]] and [[Major League Soccer]] joined forces in 2012 to create the Professional Referee Organization and the aims for PRO is to develop a higher standard of officiating at a younger age and to produce referees who can represent the United States and Canada in [[FIFA]] competitions. Then U.S. Soccer President [[Sunil Gulati]] said: “We’ve always understood that the development of referees is an important aspect to the growth of the game in the [[United States]]. “PRO is another step toward the improvement and professionalization of our top referees. With the additional resources and funding provided by the formation of PRO, we will continue to build upon the progress we’ve already made.”{{cite web|url=https://sbisoccer.com/2012/03/us-soccer-mls-creates-new-referee-program|title=U.S. Soccer, MLS create new referee program}} ==MLS Referee and Assistant Referee of the Year award== :''For a list of recipients before PRO's creation in 2012, see: [[MLS Referee of the Year Award]].'' Since PRO's inception: {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="text-align:center" |- !style="width:200px"|Year{{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/officials/mls-awards-roll-of-honor|title=MLS Awards Roll of Honor}} !style="width:200px"|Referee !style="width:200px"|Assistant Referee |- | [[2012 Major League Soccer season|2012]] | {{flagicon|CAN}}

===Notable International Appointments=== In December 2018, [[Jair Marrufo]] as [[Referee (association football)|Referee]], Frank Anderson and Corey Rockwell as [[Assistant referee (association football)|Assistant Referees]], and [[Mark Geiger]] as an [[Video assistant referee|Assistant Video Assistant Referee]], were selected to oversee the [[2018 FIFA Club World Cup Final]].{{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/2018/12/21/pro-officials-selected-to-oversee-fifa-club-world-cup-final|title=PRO officials selected to oversee FIFA Club World Cup Final}} In June 2019, [[Ismail Elfath]] as [[Referee (association football)|Referee]], Kyle Atkins and Corey Parker as [[Assistant referee (association football)|Assistant Referees]], and [[Alan Kelly (referee)|Alan Kelly]] as the [[Video assistant referee|Video Assistant Referee]] were assigned to the [[2019 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2019 FIFA Under 20 World Cup Final]].{{cite web|url=http://proreferees.com/2019/06/13/pro-crew-awarded-u-20-world-cup-final-assignment|title=PRO crew rewarded with U-20 World Cup Final assignment}} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Select Group]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=20em}} ==External links== {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com|title=Major League Soccer}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.canadasoccer.com|title=Canadian Soccer Association}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.ussoccer.com|title=US Soccer}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.nwslsoccer.com|title=National Women's Soccer League}} {{div col end}} [[Category:Association football referees]] [[Category:American soccer referees]] [[Category:Canadian soccer referees]] [[Category:Major League Soccer referees| ]] [[Category:United States Soccer Federation]] [[Category:Major League Soccer]] [[Category:Sports professional associations]] [[Category:Sports organizations established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in North America]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by 2602:30A:C043:79A0:B81D:20E3:BA8F:BDF2: Probably, but the reference from the 2018 season does not support the changes in the 2019 season. They didn't even know which teams would be playing yet. ([[WP:TW|TW]])

([[North American Football Union]]) | founded = {{start date|1993|12|17}}{{cite news|last=Borg|first=Simon|title=MLS celebrates 17th anniversary of formal debut|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/mls-celebrates-17th-anniversary-formal-debut|publisher=MLS Digital|website=MLSSoccer.com|date=December 17, 2010|access-date=September 14, 2013|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140112104012/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/mls-celebrates-17th-anniversary-formal-debut|archive-date=January 12, 2014}} | first = [[1996 Major League Soccer season|1996]] | conferences = [[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern Conference]]
[[Western Conference (MLS)|Western Conference]] | teams = 26 | promotion = none | relegation = none | levels = [[United States soccer league system|1]] | domest_cup = [[U.S. Open Cup]]
[[Canadian Championship]] | confed_cup = [[CONCACAF Champions League]]
[[Campeones Cup]]
[[Leagues Cup]] | mlscupchamps = [[Seattle Sounders FC]] (2nd title) | mlscupseason = [[2019 Major League Soccer season|2019]] | shieldchamps = [[Los Angeles FC]] (1st shield) | shieldseason = [[2019 Major League Soccer season|2019]] | most_mlscups = [[LA Galaxy]] (5 titles) | most_shields = [[D.C. United]]
[[LA Galaxy]]
(4 shields each) | most_appearances = [[Nick Rimando]] (504) | top goalscorer = [[Chris Wondolowski]] (159 goals) | tv = {{unbulleted list | '''United States''' | [[ESPN Major League Soccer|ESPN]]/[[ESPN+]] | [[MLS Soccer Sunday|Fox Sports/FS1/Fox Deportes]] | [[UniMás]]/[[TUDN (TV network)|TUDN]] | '''Canada''' | [[CTV Sports|CTV]]/[[The Sports Network|TSN]]/[[TSN2]] | [[TVA (Canada)|TVA]]/[[TVA Sports]] }} | website = {{URL|mlssoccer.com}} }} '''Major League Soccer''' ('''MLS''') is a men's professional [[association football|soccer]] league sanctioned by the [[United States Soccer Federation]] which represents the sport's highest level in the [[United States soccer league system|United States]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/about/affiliates/professional-soccer|title=About Major League Soccer|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923121329/http://www.ussoccer.com/about/affiliates/professional-soccer|archivedate=September 23, 2014}}{{cite court |litigants=Fraser v. Major League Soccer |vol=01 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=1296 |court=1st Cir. |year=2002 |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-1st-circuit/1441684.html}} The league comprises 24 teams—21 in the U.S. and 3 in Canada and constitutes one of the [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major professional sports leagues]] in both countries.{{cite web|title=MLS maintains status as most diverse professional sports league in North America|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/04/24/mls-maintains-status-most-diverse-professional-sports-league-north-america|publisher=Major League Soccer|date=April 25, 2015|accessdate=June 26, 2015|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627164041/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/04/24/mls-maintains-status-most-diverse-professional-sports-league-north-america|archivedate=June 27, 2015}}{{cite news |last=Hickey |first=Walt |url=http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/theres-a-big-five-in-north-american-pro-sports/ |title=The 'Big Five' in North American Pro Sports |work=FiveThirtyEight |date=April 4, 2014 |accessdate=May 14, 2015 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150522024423/http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/theres-a-big-five-in-north-american-pro-sports/ |archivedate=May 22, 2015 }} The league plans to expand to 29 teams with the additions of [[Inter Miami CF]] and [[Nashville SC (MLS)|Nashville SC]] in 2020,{{cite news|title=Miami MLS expansion team to begin play in 2020|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/01/29/miami-mls-expansion-team-begin-play-2020|publisher=MLS Digital|website=MLSSoccer.com|date=January 29, 2018|access-date=March 28, 2019}} [[Austin FC]] in 2021,{{cite press release|title=Austin FC to Begin Play in MLS in 2021|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/01/15/austin-fc-begin-play-mls-2021|publisher=MLS Digital|website=MLSSoccer.com|date=January 15, 2019|access-date=February 11, 2019}} [[Sacramento Republic FC (MLS)|Sacramento Republic FC]] and a [[St. Louis]] franchise in 2022,{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/soccer/ct-mls-st-louis-expansion-team-20190820-t3zy6tuipvcihim7tevuy5t74a-story.html|title=St. Louis gets an MLS expansion team and will begin play in 2022|last=Press|first=Associated|website=chicagotribune.com|access-date=August 20, 2019}} with further plans to expand to 30 teams at a later date.{{Cite web | url=https://www.stltoday.com/sports/soccer/st-louis-hailed-as-great-soccer-city-but-mls-vote/article_c2b23429-904a-5854-93a3-69c1f574c76b.html | title=St. Louis hailed as 'great soccer city,' but MLS vote on expansion is a ways off}}{{Cite web | title=MLS announces plans to expand to 30 teams | work=MLSsoccer.com | date=April 18, 2019 | access-date=April 18, 2019 | url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/04/18/mls-announces-plans-expand-30-teams }} The regular season runs from March to October, with each team playing 34 games;{{cite web|title=MLS expands playoffs, adds 2 teams in 20th season|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mls/2015/01/07/mls-expands-playoffs-adds-2-teams-in-20th-season/21398585/|work=USA Today|date=January 7, 2015|accessdate=January 8, 2015|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109034809/http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mls/2015/01/07/mls-expands-playoffs-adds-2-teams-in-20th-season/21398585/|archivedate=January 9, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Major League Soccer unveils 2015 schedule, with Decision Day finale and expanded playoff format|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/01/07/major-league-soccer-unveils-2015-schedule-decision-day-finale-and-expanded-p|website=MLSsoccer.com|publisher=Major League Soccer|date=January 7, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2015|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626225018/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2015/01/07/major-league-soccer-unveils-2015-schedule-decision-day-finale-and-expanded-p|archivedate=June 26, 2015}} the team with the best record is awarded the [[Supporters' Shield]]. Fourteen teams compete in the postseason [[MLS Cup Playoffs]] through October and November, culminating in the championship game, the [[MLS Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timbers.com/news/2013/10/mls-cup-playoffs-101-how-2013-postseason-works|title=MLS Cup Playoffs 101: How the 2013 postseason works|work=Portland Timbers|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031034335/http://www.timbers.com/news/2013/10/mls-cup-playoffs-101-how-2013-postseason-works|archivedate=October 31, 2014|date=October 29, 2013}} MLS teams also play in domestic competitions against teams from other divisions in the [[U.S. Open Cup]] and in the [[Canadian Championship]]. MLS teams also compete against continental rivals in the [[CONCACAF Champions League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/article/concacaf-approves-u-s-soccersmls-request-to-amend-their-qualification-process-to-concacaf-champions-league|title=CONCACAF Approves U.S. Soccer's/MLS Request to Amend Their Qualification Process to CCL|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008084231/http://www.concacaf.com/article/concacaf-approves-u-s-soccersmls-request-to-amend-their-qualification-process-to-concacaf-champions-league|archivedate=October 8, 2014}} With an average attendance of over 20,000 per game, MLS has the third highest average attendance of any sports league in the U.S. after the [[National Football League]] (NFL) and [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB),[[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada#Attendance]] and is the seventh highest attended professional soccer league worldwide.MLSsoccer.com, The expansion, refs, Cascadia: MLS Commissioner Don Garber covers it all in annual address, February 27, 2013, http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2013/02/27/expansion-refs-cascadia-commissioner-garber-covers-it-all-march-soccer-addre Major League Soccer was founded in 1993 as part of the United States' successful bid to host the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news |title=About Major League Soccer |publisher=MLSnet.com |date=September 5, 2008 |url=http://web.mlsnet.com/about/ |accessdate=September 5, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080625214719/http://web.mlsnet.com/about/ |archivedate = June 25, 2008}} The [[1996 Major League Soccer season|first season]] took place in 1996 with ten teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/history/season/1996|title=1996 Season Recap|work=MLSsoccer.com|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141001073656/http://www.mlssoccer.com/history/season/1996|archivedate=October 1, 2014}} MLS experienced financial and operational struggles in its first few years: the league lost millions of dollars, teams played in mostly empty American football stadiums, and two teams folded in 2002.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2013/11/20/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams/|title=Major League Soccer's Most Valuable Teams|date=November 20, 2013|work=Forbes|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921101715/http://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2013/11/20/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams/|archivedate=September 21, 2014}} Since then, MLS has [[Expansion of Major League Soccer|expanded]] to 24 teams, [[soccer-specific stadium]]s have proliferated around the league, [[Major League Soccer attendance|average attendance]] exceeds that of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) and [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA), the [[Designated Player Rule]] allows teams to sign star players such as [[David Beckham]], MLS secured [[Major League Soccer on television|national TV contracts]], and the league is now profitable.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2015/08/19/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams-2015-2/ |title=Major League Soccer's Most Valuable Teams 2015 |work=Forbes |accessdate=August 20, 2015 |first=Chris |last=Smith |date=August 19, 2015 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150820044818/http://www.forbes.com/sites/chrissmith/2015/08/19/major-league-soccers-most-valuable-teams-2015-2/ |archivedate=August 20, 2015 }} Instead of operating as an association of independently owned teams, MLS is a single entity in which each team is owned by the league and individually operated by the league's investors.{{cite court |litigants=Fraser v. Major League Soccer |vol=01 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=1296 |court=US 1st Cir. |date=March 20, 2002 |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-1st-circuit/1441684.html |quote= MLS owns all of the teams that play in the league (a total of 12 prior to the start of 2002), as well as all intellectual property rights, tickets, supplied equipment, and broadcast rights. … However, MLS has also relinquished some control over team operations to certain investors. MLS contracts with these investors to operate…the league's teams}} The investor-operators control their teams as owners control teams in other leagues, and are commonly (but inaccurately) referred to as the team's owners.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessofsoccer.com/2013/08/26/dempsey-transfer-highlights-mls-single-entity-economic-structure/|title=Dempsey Transfer Highlights Influence of MLS Single-Entity Economic Structure|work=Business of Soccer|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812084436/http://www.businessofsoccer.com/2013/08/26/dempsey-transfer-highlights-mls-single-entity-economic-structure/|archivedate=August 12, 2014|date=August 26, 2013}} The league has a fixed membership like most sports leagues in the United States and Canada, which makes it one of the world's few soccer leagues that does not use [[promotion and relegation]], a practice that is uncommon in the two countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.bigapplesoccer.com/columns/mytwocents.php?article_id=36119|title=MY TWO CENTS Part II: A few reasons how promotion/relegation system could be a success in the United States|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701145427/http://bigapplesoccer.com/columns/mytwocents.php?article_id=36119|archivedate=July 1, 2014}} MLS headquarters is located in New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.Major_League_Soccer_LLC.0432cbf68c309307.html|title=Major League Soccer, L.L.C. Company Information|publisher=Hoovers, Inc|accessdate=June 2, 2013|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928015249/http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.Major_League_Soccer_LLC.0432cbf68c309307.html|archivedate=September 28, 2013}} ==Competition format== {{See also | Supporters' Shield | MLS Cup | MLS Cup Playoffs}} Major League Soccer's regular season runs from March to October. Teams are geographically divided into the [[MLS Eastern Conference|Eastern]] and [[MLS Western Conference|Western]] Conferences, playing 34 games in a partially balanced schedule. For 2019, with 24 teams, each team plays two games (home & away) against teams in its conference and one game against each team from the opposite conference.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/schedule/2018/announcement|title=MLS releases 2018 regular-season schedule|last=|first=|date=January 4, 2018|website=|access-date=December 18, 2018}} Midway through the season, teams break for the annual [[Major League Soccer All-Star Game|All-Star Game]], an exhibition game between the league's finest players and a major club from a different league.{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/opinion/index.ssf/2014/08/mls_all-star_game_creates_oppo.html|title=MLS All-Star Game creates opportunities for Portland, U.S. soccer: Editorial|work=The Oregonian|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811214656/http://www.oregonlive.com/opinion/index.ssf/2014/08/mls_all-star_game_creates_oppo.html|archivedate=August 11, 2014}} At the end of the regular season, the team with the highest point total is awarded the [[Supporters' Shield]] and home-field advantage throughout the playoffs.{{cite web|url=http://www.brotherlygame.com/2013/8/21/4634894/a-case-for-the-supporters-shield|title=A case for the Supporters Shield|date=August 21, 2013|work=Brotherly Game|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031044518/http://www.brotherlygame.com/2013/8/21/4634894/a-case-for-the-supporters-shield|archivedate=October 31, 2014}} Unlike most major soccer leagues around the world, but similar to other leagues in the Americas,{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/zachslaton/2012/10/15/how-the-mls-playoff-format-punishes-ambitious-teams/|title=How the MLS Playoff Format Punishes Ambitious Teams|date=October 15, 2012|work=Forbes|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806183526/http://www.forbes.com/sites/zachslaton/2012/10/15/how-the-mls-playoff-format-punishes-ambitious-teams/|archivedate=August 6, 2014}} the MLS regular season is followed by a postseason knockout tournament. Fourteen teams participate in the [[MLS Cup Playoffs]] in October, which concludes with the [[MLS Cup]] championship game in early November.{{cite web |title=MLS announces new playoff format for 2019 season |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/12/13/2019-mls-playoff-structure |website=MLSsoccer.com |accessdate=January 13, 2019 |date=December 17, 2018}} Major League Soccer's spring-to-fall schedule results in scheduling conflicts with the [[Domestic association football season|FIFA calendar]] and with summertime international tournaments such as the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] and the [[CONCACAF Gold Cup|Gold Cup]],{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more_sports/2009/06/18/2009-06-18_fifa_president_sepp_blatter.html |title=FIFA president Blatter says MLS needs to adopt int'l calendar to compete |first=Michael |last=Lewis |work=Daily News|location=New York |date=June 19, 2010 |accessdate=December 22, 2010 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629083851/http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/more_sports/2009/06/18/2009-06-18_fifa_president_sepp_blatter.html |archivedate=June 29, 2011 }} causing several players to miss some MLS matches.{{cite web | url=http://articles.businessinsider.com/2010-11-22/sports/30041416_1_summer-schedule-mls-teams-don-garber | title=MLS May Change Its Schedule To Help The US's World Cup Bid | work=Business Insider | date=November 22, 2010 | accessdate=October 24, 2011 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113134122/http://articles.businessinsider.com/2010-11-22/sports/30041416_1_summer-schedule-mls-teams-don-garber | archivedate=January 13, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} While MLS has looked into changing to a fall-to-spring format, there are no current plans to do so. If the league were to change its schedule, a substantial winter break would still be necessary due to teams being located in harsh winter climates.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2010-11-21-2487717250_x.htm |title=MLS looks at switching to international schedule |work=USA Today |date=November 22, 2011 |accessdate=October 24, 2011 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107134551/http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2010-11-21-2487717250_x.htm |archivedate=January 7, 2012 }}{{cite press release |url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/playoffs-expand-10-teams-more-changes-ahead |title=Playoffs expand to 10 teams, more changes ahead |publisher=Major League Soccer |date=November 22, 2010 |accessdate=December 22, 2010 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227160017/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/playoffs-expand-10-teams-more-changes-ahead |archivedate=December 27, 2010 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/mls/2011-02-14-garber-mls-schedule_N.htm |title=MLS' Garber: No plans for international calendar |work=USA Today |date=February 15, 2011 |accessdate=October 19, 2011 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107114514/http://www.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/mls/2011-02-14-garber-mls-schedule_N.htm |archivedate=January 7, 2012 }} It would also have to compete with the popularity and media presence of the [[National Football League]] (NFL) in the fall and winter as well as the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) and [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), which both run on fall-to-spring schedules. ===Other competitions=== {{See also|MLS performance in the CONCACAF Champions League | Campeones Cup}} MLS teams also play in other international and domestic competitions. Every year, five MLS teams — four from the U.S. and one from Canada — play in the [[CONCACAF Champions League]] against other clubs from the [[CONCACAF]] region (Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean). Two U.S.-based MLS teams qualify based on MLS regular-season results: the winner of the Western conference and the winner of the Eastern conference. The third U.S. team to qualify is the winner of the [[MLS Cup]]. A fourth U.S.-based MLS team can qualify via the [[U.S. Open Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/lamar-hunt-us-open-cup|title=Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140920220525/http://www.ussoccer.com/lamar-hunt-us-open-cup|archivedate=September 20, 2014}} If a team qualifies through multiple berths, or if any of the MLS berths are taken by a Canada-based MLS team, the berth is reallocated to the best U.S.-based team in the Supporters' Shield table that has otherwise not qualified. Canadian MLS clubs play against other Canadian clubs in the [[Canadian Championship]] for the one CONCACAF Champions League spot allocated to Canada.{{cite web |date=March 21, 2014 |title=Canada Soccer announces move to new timeframe for future Amway Canadian Championships |url=http://www.canadasoccer.com/canada-soccer-annonce-un-nouveau-calendrier-pour-les-prochaines-éditions-du-championnat-canadien-amway-p156082&language=en |publisher=Canada Soccer |accessdate=August 1, 2014 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016060453/http://www.canadasoccer.com/canada-soccer-annonce-un-nouveau-calendrier-pour-les-prochaines-%C3%A9ditions-du-championnat-canadien-amway-p156082%26language%3Den |archivedate=October 16, 2014 }} No MLS club has won the Champions League since it began its current format in 2008, but MLS teams have reached the final three times: Real Salt Lake in 2011, Montreal Impact in 2015, and Toronto FC in 2018.{{cite news |last=Goff |first=Steven |date=April 10, 2018 |title=Toronto FC ousts Club America, earns berth in Concacaf Champions League finals |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2018/04/11/toronto-fc-ousts-club-america-earns-berth-in-concacaf-champions-league-final/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=June 1, 2019}} Since 2018, the previous year's MLS Cup champion plays in the [[Campeones Cup]], a single game against the [[Campeón de Campeones]] from [[Liga MX]], hosted by the MLS team in September.{{cite press release |date=March 13, 2018 |title=Major League Soccer and Liga MX Fuel Rivalry with New Partnership |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/03/13/major-league-soccer-and-liga-mx-fuel-rivalry-new-partnership |publisher=Major League Soccer |accessdate=March 13, 2018}} The inaugural edition saw [[Tigres UANL]] defeat Toronto FC 3–1 on September 19, 2018, at BMO Field in Toronto.{{cite news |last=Shoalts |first=David |date=September 19, 2018 |title=Mexico's Tigres get a little payback, defeat Toronto FC in Campeones Cup |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/article-mexicos-tigres-get-a-little-payback-defeat-toronto-fc-in-campeones/ |work=The Globe and Mail |accessdate=June 1, 2019}} Another inter-league competition, the [[Leagues Cup]], was established in 2019 and will pair four MLS clubs against four Liga MX clubs in a single-elimination tournament hosted in the United States, reviving an inter-league rivalry that previously took place in the now defunct [[North American Superliga]].{{cite news |last=Marshall |first=Tom |date=May 29, 2019 |title=MLS and Liga MX announce Leagues Cup |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3863630/mls-and-liga-mx-announce-leagues-cup |publisher=[[ESPN]] |accessdate=June 1, 2019}} ==Teams== {{See also|Expansion of Major League Soccer|Major League Soccer defunct clubs|List of Major League Soccer coaches|List of Major League Soccer stadiums}} {{MLS labeled map}} MLS's 24 teams are divided between the [[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern]] and [[Western Conference (MLS)|Western Conference]]s. Each club is allowed up to 28 players on its first team roster.{{cite news|title=MLS Roster Rules and Regulations|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/league/official-rules/mls-roster-rules-and-regulations|publisher=MLS Digital|website=MLSsoccer.com|date=March 2, 2018|access-date=February 13, 2019}} All 28 players are eligible for selection to each 18-player game-day squad during the regular season and playoffs. MLS has regularly expanded since the 2005 season. The league plans to expand to 29 teams with the addition of [[Inter Miami CF]] and [[Nashville SC (MLS)|Nashville SC]] in 2020, [[Austin FC]] in 2021, and [[Sacramento Republic FC (MLS)|Sacramento Republic FC]] and [[St. Louis MLS team|St. Louis]] in 2022,{{cite web |last1=Bogert |first1=Tom |title=Major League Soccer awards expansion team to St. Louis |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2019/08/20/mls-awards-expansion-team-st-louis |website=MLSSoccer.com |publisher=Major League Soccer |accessdate=August 20, 2019}} with further plans to expand to 30 teams at a later date. MLS is currently the largest first division professional soccer league in the world. The league features numerous [[MLS rivalry cups|rivalry cups]] that are contested by two or more teams, usually geographic rivals. Each trophy is awarded to the team with the better regular-season record in games involving the two teams. The concept is comparable to rivalry trophies played for by U.S. [[college football]] teams.{{cite web|url=http://www.ussoccerplayers.com/2014/01/derby-or-rivalry-in-mls.html|title=Derby or Rivalry in MLS?|accessdate=September 20, 2014|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222003624/http://www.ussoccerplayers.com/2014/01/derby-or-rivalry-in-mls.html|archivedate=February 22, 2014}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="background:white"|Team ! style="background:white"|City, State ! style="background:white"|Arena ! style="background:white"|Capacity ! style="background:white"|Joined ! style="background:white"|Head coach |- ! style="background:#1D428A;" colspan="6"|[[Eastern Conference (MLS)|Eastern Conference]] |- | '''[[Atlanta United FC]]''' | [[Atlanta, Georgia]] | [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]]{{ref|1|1}} | align=center|42,500{{ref|4|4}} | align=center|2017 | [[Frank de Boer]] |- | '''[[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire SC]]''' | [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]] | [[Soldier Field]]{{ref|1|1}} | align=center|24,995 | align=center|1998 | vacant |- | '''[[FC Cincinnati]]''' | [[Cincinnati|Cincinnati, Ohio]] | [[Nippert Stadium]]{{ref|1|1}} {{ref|2|2}} | align=center|32,250 | align=center|2019 | [[Ron Jans]] |- | '''[[Columbus Crew SC]]''' | [[Columbus, Ohio]] | [[Mapfre Stadium]] | align=center|19,968 | align=center|1996 | [[Caleb Porter]] |- | '''[[D.C.
